text: One of the most typical scenes of the day: a mass picket  line outside a textile or shoe factory. And the picketing anything but peaceful; the demonstrators are in direct  conflict with the police, who are trying to keep an entra open for strike-breakers. Whatever the general action, a  small segment of struggle breaks off from it, and it is t that our CAMERA picks up: some police chasing some picket or some pickets chasing some strike-breakers, the one fac pursuing the other up an alley with violent intent.
A couple of the pursuers catch up to the pursued and assa them with clubs or other weapons. The fighting is bitter, dirty and noisy.

location: KITCHEN IN SLEAZY RESTAURANT NEAR RAILROAD

text: The eight men gathered here in a game of five-card stud a clearly removed from the struggle outside, even though th SOUNDS of it are very close, coming through window openin on the alley. In fact the noise is so loud that the DEALE of the hand in progress reacts in annoyance.
Somebody shut the goddam window. Let  a man think.

The player nearest the window shuts it. The Dealer, who a owns the restaurant, is the talkative type of poker playe Except for THE CINCINNATI KID, the other men at the table look like hoods of one sort or another: gunmen, labor spi extortionists, what have you. The man who fancies himself the toughest of them all is named DANNY, and he and The K have almost all the money on the table between them, abou hundred dollars in front of each. No other player has mor than a few dollars left, and now, as fifth cards are deal there is about forty dollars in the pot. Only four men ar left in the hand.
Possible straight gets a -- (deals the card) -- lovely little four.
On the last hand even, you couldn't  give me a break.
I put the brakes on your straight,  didn't I? (he laughs; no one  else does; he deals  to The Kid) There you are, son, a gorgeous deuce.
Thanks.
(deals to Danny) And our lucky friend from Chicago  gets a queen with his pair of sixes.  Little lady make you happy, Buster?
Deal to yourself, clown.
Dealer gives himself a -- (deals card and groans) I might have known. (to Danny) Bet your sixes, Buster.
I told you not to call me that. (then as the dealer  turns away) Cost you -- (counts out his money) Ninety-four bucks.
Biggest pot of the whole game, I got  to drop.
(to First Player) Interested?
Wouldn't call you if I had a pair  higher'n sixes. Which I ain't.
He turns over his cards, leaving it up to The Kid.

Don't seem like he'd bet out without  something better than the sixes,  does it? (fingers hole card as  if to fold) Cost me every cent I've won since  yesterday afternoon. (studies Danny's face) But I tell you, I got this stubborn  streak. Call the ninety-four dollars.
He counts out the money, which is almost all he has.
(indignantly) You can't have better than a pair of  kings!
Oh, I'm not claiming anything that  fine. (turns over an eight,  making a pair of  them) Just enough to beat the pair of sixes.
You seen my hole card, you bastard! (indicating Dealer) He was dealing them high.
Attending to first things first, The Kid has been pulling the pot, adding it to his own stake, and pocketing the to Now as Danny accuses him again, The Kid looks him squarel in the face.
You stole that dough.
You better watch those loose lips of  yours, you want to have any teeth  left behind them -- Buster.
He stands up.
You wouldn't of shelled out ninety- four bucks --
I called you on account of I didn't  think you had another pair or another  six and I know a punk like you would  get greedy and try and buy the last  hand.
He walks off, disappearing through a door marked "MEN."

He is waiting when the door opens abruptly, and Danny app his right hand in his coat pocket. The Kid's hand goes to his own pocket and as he whirls around, a straight razor  appears in it, its blade snapped open. Pushing Danny to t wall with one hand, he keeps him pinned there with the ra in the other, while he bolts the door. Danny gets his rig hand out of the pocket with a gun in it, but The Kid move the razor blade against his neck.
Drop it.

As the gun clatters to the floor, and the others force th door, The Kid takes a step backward to provide enough  momentum, then swings at Danny's middle with his left,  dropping him, then jumps up on the wash basin and wriggle his way out through a window.
Danny recovers his balance and his gun, unbolts the door  just before it is smashed in, and runs with the others to get out of the building and after The Kid.

The conflicting parties from the picket lines have moved The Kid drops from the window to the ground and starts to run toward the railroad yards. A few moments later, Danny and four other poker players appear and run after him.

The chase across the tracks goes on behind the Credits. T Kid's pursuers split into two groups to cut him off, and  they seem to have succeeded in cornering him against a tr on which a passenger train is bearing down, headed for th station. His dubious chance of escape depends on his gett beyond this track in front of the train, which, with a bu of speed, he manages to accomplish just in time. The pass train divides The Kid from his pursuers, and we PAN with train into the depot.

The train slowly stops. Amid all the atmosphere of arriva in a day when the Pullman car was still the ultimate in  travel, LANCEY HODGES appears on a platform, takes his ba from the Pullman porter and passes it on to a Red Cap bef he has descended the steps. He walks with other passenger and Red Caps toward the center of the station.
Shooting through the Meeting of the Rivers fountain acros Market Street to the Romanesque building with its campani
Lancey getting into a taxi.
Lancey sits in serene repose in back, watching the sights by. The HACKIE steals a couple of looks at him in the rea vision mirror.
What you looking for, mister?
Do I have to be looking for something?
I can pretty much tell.
You can pretty much tell what?
Some guys come to town, I can tell  if they're looking for something.
What do you think I'm looking for?
If you're looking for girls, I can  fix you up.
I strongly doubt if you could fix me  up. In that department.
Well what are you looking for?
You're looking for a clout in the  head if you don't keep your face to  the road.
A doorman takes Lancey's suitcase as Lancey pays the Hack and walks into the hotel. A SECOND HACKIE whose cab is at the curb reacts to seeing Lancey and steps forward.
Hey, you know who that is?
No. Who?
But the second hackie has followed Lancey into the hotel.
Lancey crosses to the desk to register as the Second Hack goes to a row of phone booths and enters one. He dials wi his eyes on Lancey registering.
(into phone) Shorty? Want to hear who just checked  into the Park Sherman... Yes, you  do. Lancey Hodges.
He is talking on the phone while he hands out score sheet and shoes to some bowlers. He is just as excited by the r as the Hackie is.
The Kid know?
He is talking on the telephone behind the bar.
Somebody sure as hell ought to tell  The Kid. (hangs up) Lancey Hodges is in town.
He reacts to the news in a big way. CAMERA PANS to anothe DRINKING MAN, who is equally impressed. They exchange loo
Kid's been laying for him a long  time.
You ask me, The Kid'll go after him  as soon as he hears.
Who's got a better right?
We are in the front room where the pool tables are. Throu an open door in b.g., we can see the unadvertised but  unconcealed other activity of the establishment: a poker  game in progress.
You going to tell The Kid, Shooter?
Hell, I can't not tell him.
It's where he's been headed for years.
The Kid enters the place through the front door, still a  little dishevelled from his escape.
(in greeting) Hey!
What you say, Kid?
Hey, Hoban.
Where you been? Boys been holding a  chair for you in back.
Business opportunity come along.  Something too good to pass up.
Turn a profit?
Yeah, did okay. Except I almost had  it took back.
Oh, one of those.
(concerned) You been in too many rough ones  lately, Kid. You can't go on forever,  coming out in one piece.
I got to build my stake, Aren't enough  chances in this town to let one go.
You're too good, that's your trouble.  People who know you're the Cincinnati  Kid, they don't want to sit down  with you --
For nickels and dimes... Thing is  I've about used up St. Louis.
(nodding) The streets are getting full of guys  you've hustled.
Been thinking about Miami. There's  nothing to keep me here.
(after a moment) The hell there isn't (as the Kid looks at  him) Lancey Hodges' in town.
Yeah? (then) The Man himself, here in St. Louis --  I might just stick around Shooter.
Lancey is on the phone, sitting on the bed.

(into phone) Mr. Schlaegel? How are you? And your  enchanting wife?... Tomorrow is quite  convenient... I generally prefer  stud but you name it... Your stakes  are my pleasure, sir... Thank you,  why don't we make it after lunch? My  diet these days is enough to spoil  anyone else's appetite... A pleasure,  sir. Please remember me to your  charming wife.
He hangs up and some of the strength seems to go out of h as if he had been through too long a sustained effort. Hi eyes show that he is feeling pain and he breathes deeply.
Harold Street leads to the river and we follow The Kid an The Shooter as they walk down it in the gathering dusk.
(lighting a cigar) I been seeing it coming for a long  time, Kid. Long time.
I ain't exactly been hiding it.
No, you ain't been hiding it.
Well I got to know.
Sure, you got to know. We all got to  know.
Sometime or other we got to find out  how much juice we got.
That's why I had to tell you.
You ever sit down with him?
Yes, I have.
They walk along, The Shooter pursing his lips thoughtfull
Well, what happened?
Nothing. Nothing at all.
You lost.
I didn't lose. I'm too good to lose  when I set my mind to it. I play  poker a certain way, Kid. I've had  my Lancey Hodges. Only with me it  was Whistling Sam Magee to New  Orleans.
(respectfully) I heard about him.
Well then you know it all... about  20 years ago it was, maybe more.
What happened?
Why, I lost it. It dried me up on  the inside for a long, a very long  time.
Yeah?
I been where I'm going, know what I  mean?
The Kid nods as they come to where an old wooden pier ext into the river. Along the river bank can be seen a small  portion of the mile-long Hooverville that stretches up an down the Mississippi.
They walk out on the pier and eventually stop, look out a the river, watching the working boats. They have their  thoughts; The Shooter smoking his cigar.
You think I'm ready?
(after some time,  several seconds of  thoughtful puffing) Kid, I don't think you're ready.
(quickly) Oh.
But you're not going to take my word  for it, are you? Are you now?
No, I ain't. I can't.
I know, I know. You got to find out  for yourself.
I don't figure to take him right  away. But if I can hang in there  long enough, I can outlast him. If I  can outlast him, I got a chance. You  admit that, don't you, that I got a  chance?
I already said I didn't think you  were ready.
Did you think you were ready when  you sat down with Whistling Sam Magee?
Kid, I thought I was the best stud  poker player in the world. I'm telling  you now, I thought I was the best.
Well, I don't think I'm just a cocky  square with a fair hand with cards.  I got something.
No, you ain't no cocky square. And  you probably got something.
Okay. And I ain't saying that you  was either when you sat down with  Whistling Sam Magee.
If you got the stuff, being a little  cocky don't hurt you none.
Well, would you say if I got any  chance at all?
This much of a chance. If Lancey is  not right. If he's got a cold, or  his stomach ulcer is acting up, or  something like that.
But then everybody'd see he wasn't  right and it wouldn't prove nothing.  Listen, we got to have it understood.  If he's not right, we call it off  till he is.
You're set on a real showdown, aren't  you? Your mind's all made up.
They start back off the pier.
I got to. You said yourself I got  to. I'm overdue.
Yeah, you been around a long time --  I was a lot younger than you when I  went up against Whistling Sam -- But  you'd be kinda young too, to be The  Man.
I gotta find out.
(after a pause) Want me to set it up?
(gratefully) I wish you would, Shooter Man.
All right.
Hey, what if he turns me down?
He won't, the way I'll spread the  word. He'll have to take you on,  someone in your class. If he ducked  it, that'd make you The Man.
You think he knows I'm around?
He can smell meat like you a mile  and a half up the river. He knows  you're around and he'll sit down  with you. You want to butt heads  with The Man, I'll set it up.
Ahead, on the levee, CHRISTIAN is seen waiting for The Ki She has not yet seen them as they approach off the pier.
There's your woman.
I wouldn't want to wait around too  long. I want to get in and get it  over with.
He must of come to St. Louis for a  big money game. I'll probably get  asked do I want to deal it for them.  And however long that takes, he'll  have to rest up for you.
Oh, well, if he's tooling a dollar,  I can understand that. Sure.
You got much of a stake?
Close to three grand.

Work on it. But three grand will  give you a ride and even if you don't  win, why you'll come away with a  good idea of what you're made of.  But once you go in Kid you can't  quit. You get that straight right  now. Two of you go in and only one  of you can come out.
Christian sees them and moves toward them.
Well, school's out. I damn sure don't  want no lessons. I want everything  he's got.
It's the only way to be, Kid.
Shooter turns away abruptly as Christian arrives, giving a brief nod.
See you.
The Kid takes Christian's arm automatically; he watches T Shooter walk way down Harold Street. He and Christian hea in another direction. She is humming a mountain tune.
When we leaving town, Kid? This week?
No, I won't be ready. Not for a while.
I thought --
Might even turn out we don't go.
She is surprised by this and, in her own hesitant way,  curious.
You must feel different about it  than you did Saturday.
He looks at her fondly and, for one fleeting moment of  weakness, is actually tempted to tell her about Lancey. B it is too sharp a break with tradition.
Yeah, I'm feeling a little different.

It is night and the room is lit only by a single lamp whe Christian sits in her nightgown on a chair by the window, turning over the pages of a mail-order catalogue. In f.g. The Kid lies on his back under a sheet on the bed, his ey closed and his hands clasped tensely behind his neck. He  opens his eyes and turns to look at her. The movement cat her eye, and she instantly stops turning the pages, afrai the noise has disturbed him.
It's all right. You don't have to  act like a cat. You're not bothering  me.
You want me to turn out the light?
No. I'm overtired, that's why I can't  sleep. (sits up and swings  his feet to the floor) Why can't you sleep?

(lightly) Undertired, I guess. If a person  rests all day, she doesn't have much  to rest up from at night. (stands up) Why don't you have a nice hot bath?  I could give you a rubdown and then  you could have a nice hot bath, and  then maybe you could sleep.
She waits at the foot of the bed for him to come slowly t decision.
'Kay. Can't hurt to try it.

She goes into the bathroom, where she turns the water on  gently so the tub will take a long while to fill. Then sh takes a bottle of alcohol from the medicine chest and ret to the bedroom with it. She stands in front of him waitin for him to move, but The Kid is singularly listless. Not  till she sets the bottle down does he respond by turning face to the pillow. She goes right to work on his shoulde muscles, and she seems to know what she is doing.
What did you do with yourself this  time?
Last night I went to a movie with  The Shooter's woman. French movie.
In French?
They had the words in English at the  bottom of the picture. But The  Shooter's woman knew what they were  saying without it. Pig's woman or  somebody told me she went to college.
Sure. Majored in man-eating.
I think maybe she really did go. But  I never quite dared to up and ask  her.
I didn't know you ran with The  Shooter's woman.
We got to be kind of friendly when  you both were in that three-day game  down to Cairo. 'Course she's older'n  me.
And been around more. A lot more.  What was the movie like?
Weird. It wasn't a straight story  where you knew whose side you were  on, the way you do in regular  pictures.
American pictures.
Yeah. There were lots of things I  didn't understand.
What was it about?

Well, there's this town in Europe a  long time ago where they get a message  from a Spanish general he's coming  to spend the night with his troops.  So all the men are scared silly about  what the soldiers will do to them.
Nothing weird about that.
But all the wives and daughters tell  the men to go hide somewhere and let  them bargain with the enemy.
That don't make much sense.
Wait. The way they handle it is they  go to bed with the Spaniards. And  the next morning the soldiers go off  peacefully and everybody's happy.
Including the husbands and fathers?  Don't they suspect?
That's part of what I wasn't sure  of. I guess they know what went on  but they care more about their safety  and their money than they do about  their honor.
Then they got their heads screwed on  straight. Honor's just an idea. You  can't see or feel it and you can't  eat it and you sure as hell can't  get any mileage on it.
She slaps him on the rump and straightens up.
I'll just turn off the bath water.
He doesn't move but just stays relaxed and closes his eye

Christian, humming softly, turns off the water, takes a l towel from a rack and puts it on a stool by the tub where will be more convenient for him. She lingers to test the  water with her finger and do anything else she can think to assure maximum comfort for her man. Then she steps bac into the bedroom. The sight of him makes her advance  cautiously and confirm her suspicion that he is asleep.
MELBA, The Shooter's woman, is sitting up in bed working her eyebrows and listening to MUSIC turned up LOUD on a r The bedside phone RINGS, barely audible above the radio. answers it.
(into phone) Hello... Yes, it is. You want him? (calling) Shooter! Telephone! Shooter!

She gets no answer, which is no wonder in view of the noi from the radio. But the radio is across the room and it's slightly easier for her to get out of the side of the bed she's on, and go to the door of The Shooter's room. She o this and we see The Shooter in bed in his own small quart reading a magazine. He turns around inquiringly.
Phone for you. I always seem to be  the one to answer it, no matter who  it's for.
(getting up) If you'd rather we put it in my room --
Are you kidding?

The Shooter picks up the phone but before he speaks into he pantomimes to her that he won't be able to hear over t radio. She seems to regard the request as an imposition b she does go grudgingly to the radio and turns it down a l before she returns to her bed and her cosmetic chore.
(into phone) Hello?... Well, hello. What brings  you to our fair city? Little action,  maybe?
Lancey, dressed for bed, is on the phone.
(into phone) How could you guess, Shooter? I was  invited by a Mr. William Schlaegel --
(into phone) Owns most of the Schlaegel Brewery.  Braumeister beer.

The Shooter sits down on the edge of Melba's bed, the mov jostling her so she pricks herself with her tweezers. She exclaims in protest and gives him a dirty look that makes The Shooter stand right up again.

(into phone) As he put it, rather bluntly, I felt,  we don't want everyone to have to  watch everyone else dealing to see  to it they don't make any little  accidental errors by mistake. I told  him a man couldn't ask for a better  guarantee of a fair-and-square game  than having The Shooter deal it. So  if you're willing, we're meeting at  two o'clock in the afternoon. Ask  for Mr. Schlaegel's suite at the  Park Sherman... Good. I'm glad you  can do it, Shooter. Be a pleasure to  see you again... (then) Oh pretty much the same... Just have  to be a little careful about smoking  and drinking and eating -- and  breathing. See you tomorrow. Good  night.
He hangs up the phone, settles himself in a comfortable c and opens a heavy book. CAMERA MOVES in CLOSE enough to r the title: Prescott's CONQUEST OF PERU.

It is midday outside but the window shades are tightly dr to keep the daylight from disturbing The Kid, who is stil asleep. Christian, dressed for the street, moves from the bedroom to the kitchen-living room which is the remainder the two-room apartment. Finding paper and pencil, she wri a quick note and leaves it on the kitchen table, then sta out. (TIME LAPSE)

featuring one bathing suit displayed among others in an e of-season sale with some such advertising message as "All bathing suits reduced 1/3 for clearance!" The particular  suit is a two-piece one, exposing two or three inches of  bare midriff -- the first modest forerunner of the trend  that led eventually to the bikini.
Would you wear it in public?
CAMERA PULLS BACK to include Christian and Melba looking the display.
Wouldn't be much point wearing it in  private. Sure, why not, as long as  you don't have a bulge to hide?
They start walking.
I don't know, Melba.
(looking her over) My guess is there isn't anything  about you needs hiding. But I'll  give you a more definitive opinion  at the bath.
(startled) At the what?
Turkish Bath. After we're through  shopping. I'm treating you, Christian.
I never been. I'm not even sure what  you do.
You don't do anything. That's what's  so marvelous. They do it to you. (TIME LAPSE)
CAMERA finds Christian and Melba among the perspiring fem
The third time I stayed. Never went  back to the boarding house except to  pick up my things.
And that side of it's held up? No  complaints in the bed department?
Well, just one.
(intrigued) Yes?
The nights he isn't there.
He really does that to you, does he?  You got one of the rare ones. (TIME LAPSE)

Christian and Melba are on adjoining rubbing tables, a cu separating them from the waist down only. Their heads are close enough so they can talk without their masseurs  necessarily hearing every word they say.
You find a guy, you love him, and  that's it. It's supposed to just go  on like that for life. Right?
According to the propaganda, right.
But it isn't my life, it's his life,  with me tacked on. You have any idea  what it's like to be a hash slinger  in a cheap restaurant?
No, honey, the stock crash wafted me  right from the daisy chain into  unmarried bliss.
It's hell, if you'll excuse the word.  But I didn't want to quit. The Kid  made me. I felt I ought to hang on  to something that was me away from  him. You know what I mean?
Sure. Some girls solve the problem  by taking on an extra guy.
I'm serious. Having children might  take care of it, I don't know. Or --  this is really a terrible thing to  admit.
Your most sordid secrets are safe  with me. Confess.
If he was rich, or famous --
Why don't you give him both?
(smiling) Why not? Well, if he was rich and  famous, maybe I wouldn't mind so  much just being -- just a woman to  him. Do you think that might make it  seem more worthwhile somehow?
Somehow! Are you sincere, sweetie? (reacting to the  masseur's touch) Oooo -- divine. (to Christian) Isn't this heaven?
I'm not sure. In a way it seems soft  of --
She is at a loss for a word.
Decadent? Depraved?
Christian looks blank.
Wicked?
Well, yes.
That's what I meant by heaven.

Lancey, Shooter and five other men are sitting in comfort padded chairs around a well-appointed poker table. Everyt about the game is in sharp contrast to the one The Kid pl in. It is played with chips - expensive ones; there are a couple of bottles of wine on ice, fine cigars, a tray of  sandwiches, etc. Lancey's opponents are all wealthy types two of them could be Texas oil men. The youngest, a good- looking man of thirty, is BILL SCHLAEGEL. The Shooter, as nonplaying dealer, distributes fifth cards to the four  remaining players in the hand, and both Lancey and Bill e up with four cards of one suit showing.
(as he deals) Still queens -- possible flush -- no  help -- possible flush.
Queens check to the possibles.
Check.
Check.
Bill silently tosses in two of the rarest and highest ran chips on the table.
Fold.
And up two.
Fold.
Biggest pot yet.
A phone RINGS and the Third Wealthy Type answers it.
Call the two thou.
(turning over queen  of his suit) Queen high.
(indignantly) Jack high. Can you beat that?
He just did.
(to Second Wealthy  Type) It's your office.
Dallas or Tulsa?
She just said office.

The Third Wealthy Type takes the phone and speaks on it d the ensuing. The Second Wealthy Type crosses to the bar a fixes himself a drink. Lancey takes in his winnings. Bill hasn't recovered from the blow. There is a hiatus in the  game.
How the bloody hell did you figure  out I didn't have the king or the  ace?

I recollect a young fellow putting  the same question to Eddie the Dude.  It was a game in the grand lounge of  the "J.M. White, Third," the largest  paddle-wheeler ever built. "Son,"  Eddie told him, "All you paid was  the looking price. Lessons are extra." (turns to Shooter) First time I heard of this Cincinnati  Kid was in New Orleans, at Yeller's.  I knew right away I'd have to play  him someday.
You'll enjoy his game.
I may admire it. But if he's all  that good, I doubt if I'll enjoy it.
The tougher the competition, the  better you used to like it.
I've learned to take everything in  moderation.
It is early evening. The Kid approaches the restaurant wi Christian on one arm, Melba on the other.
(to Melba) Have a drink with us?
Better not. Shooter said they'd break  at seven, and he has to have his  food first, then his nap. (looking The Kid over) You know, there's a day in your life  I'm looking forward to.
In my life?
The day The Kid becomes The Man.
She smiles at them both and goes off. They move to enter restaurant. (TIME LAPSE)
The plates with the remains of their main course are in f of them. The Kid pours what's left of a bottle of beer in his glass.
How'd you sleep Kid?
I slept okay.
I hope you don't mind my not being  there when you woke up.
No I don't mind -- (then) What she was talking about, Shooter's  woman -- I'm going up against a big  game soon.
She told me. It's a very big game, I  hear.
Yes.
Will it be long?
Why? (then) What's the matter?
I thought --
Thought what?
I'd go home and see Mama.
I wouldn't be able to spare you much  change.
Oh, I wouldn't want much. Bus is  really the best way to go.
Would a hundred fish do it? For the  bus and something nice to bring your  Mama?
That would be fine, Kid. Just fine.
When would you want to go?
There's no reason for not going right  now unless --
She lowers her eyes, finding it hard to say the words.
Unless what?
Unless you wanted to go to bed first.
Do you want to? Would you like it?
Un-huh. I'd like it.
You want dessert?
No. You?
(shakes head) Coffee?
I don't need it.
Neither do I.
He looks o.s. raising a hand to summon the check. (TIME LAPSE)

It is dark in the room and dark outside, the street lamps furnishing only enough light for a faint border around th window shade. Christian's head and nude back move into th Shot; she pulls the shade aside to look out.
The time is a few minutes before ten.

She lets the shade fall back into place. Moving quietly i the darkness, she begins to dress. CAMERA PULLS BACK and  PANS to include The Kid, lying on the bed with a sheet ov him. He seems to be asleep until he speaks.
You still haven't said it.
Said what?
If you're coming back.
Christian abandons the process of dressing herself and si down in the easy chair to answer this question.
Maybe I ought to stay with Mama and  Papa a while, and see.
What's to see?
I never did like city streets.
Oh.
Uh-huh. The promise didn't fulfill  itself for me.
Promise?
Come to the city and all. Electric  lights and flush toilets. All the  pretty dreams -- it was all promise.
Oh, I see.
I don't know if you do or not Kid --  You're city -- and I'm country --  You grew up with it.
I don't think that's why you're going --  because you like it so much better  in the country.
She doesn't comment one way or the other, nor does he pre the point.
What will you do?
Well, I've got that big game.
I heard he's The Man for you.
Yes. If I won, there would be a lot  of money.
You'll win. You been coming on strong  a long way. This is your time. (then after a long  moment) Come home with me to Mama's Kid.
(finally) I'm sorry.
(gently) I know you are honey -- I know it.
She gets up and begins to pack her clothes in an old suit After a moment The Kid gets out of bed.
I'll go down to the bus with you.
You don't have to.
(starting to dress) I'll go down with you.
(after a pause) Kid --
Yeah?
This is going to sound kind of funny  to you, but I want to ask it.
Sure.

Do you think there's any chance, if  you do win this big game, that you  might do something else besides cards? (hastily) I don't mean never play poker. I  just mean not have it be the only  thing you do.

Hell, it's the only thing I know how  to do. What else is there for a guy  never finished school? College  graduates are walking the streets  looking for jobs -- trained people,  engineers, scientists!
I realize --

(not letting her speak) When you're The Man, you don't have  to hustle -- When you're The Man,  The Best, the Big Money comes around  on their knees just beggin' to hustle  you. I'm not goin' to quit. I'm goin'  to win.
Yes, I can see that. Of course I  didn't say quit.
Well you see how it is.
That's all right.
(after a moment) Christian, you aren't doing this to  be off my back, in case I lose?
I been thinking about it a long time.  I been planning to go home and see  how I felt about things.
And this just helped you decide.
That's all.
Then don't go.
(firmly) No, this is your time -- Now you go  on Honey and you play The Man --  I'll be at Mama's.

She closes the suitcase and puts on the one dress she has packed. The Kid, dressed now, watches her for a moment th goes to the bottom drawer of the dresser and opens it to  reveal a stack of money under a shirt. He takes five clea twenty-dollar bills and counts them on to the top of the  dresser, snapping the crisp leaves gambler style. Then he stoops down again and takes out two more twenties, adding them to the pile.
I wish it could be more.
That's all right.

He doesn't actually hand her the money. He leaves it on t of the dresser and she goes over and takes it, folding th bills and putting them in her change purse. The Kid picks her suitcase, and she leads the way into the other room. the front door she stops and looks back at the little  apartment for a moment.
I don't guess I'll ever forget these  rooms, Kid.
I don't guess I will either.
You going to move?
If I win, it won't be good enough.  If I lose, I lose it all.
She looks at him for a moment, then exits. He follows. (TIME LAPSE)
The Kid and Christian sit in silence. She puts her hand o his. (TIME LAPSE)

The Kid and Christian sit on a bench in the waiting room, still silent. He has her suitcase between his legs and a  pile of magazines on his lap. She looks at a clock and ge to her feet. He follows her to the door, carrying the sui and magazines.
Christian boards a bus that has seen better days. On the  steps she turns to take the bag from him, but he follows on.
Christian takes a seat. The Kid puts her suitcase in the  overhead rack and hands her the magazines, none of which  would be classed as heavy reading.
Goodbye, Kid. Good luck.
Goodbye, Christian.
They don't kiss. He turns and goes out.

There are not many passengers boarding this bus. After a  couple of moments, the driver closes the door and starts  off. Christian waves from the window, and The Kid waves b to her. When the bus has gone, he walks around the outsid of the terminal to the front.
There are a couple of cabs at a taxi stand. One of the ha offers his services to The Kid, but The Kid declines. He  wants to walk. (TIME LAPSE)
It is midday and the poker game is almost twenty- four ho old. Our attention is focused on Bill Schlaegel, who is  writing out a check.
Four stacks? Right, Schooter?
Four.
The Shooter takes advantage of the lull in the proceeding to move to the telephone.
Thank you for the entertainment,  gentlemen. My particular gratitude  to you, Lancey. It's been a rare  pleasure to watch a great artist at  work. Thank you for the privilege.
Lancey gives him a quick look, finding this a bit thick.
Well now, son, you're quite welcome.  Can't say I recall another man, in  all my days on the three rivers, who  seemed to find it quite so pleasurable  losing all that money.
Bill puts his check down in front of The Shooter's place, and gets to his feet.
Good day, gentlemen. You're welcome  to use the premises as long as you  like.

CAMERA MOVES with Bill as he passes The Shooter, who is  waiting on the phone while the hotel operator dials his  number. Bill gives him a friendly pat on the back, and sp in a low, harsh voice for The Shooter's ears alone.
I want to see you.
Bill goes out. Shooter looks after him as his party comes the phone.
(into phone) Hi, Kid. Shooter here. Listen, I  told the woman I'd take her to the  ball park, but I'm still working.  How about you and Christian take her  out?
(into phone) Christian's gone home to see her  folks.
(into phone) Oh. (then) Well listen, would you mind taking  her yourself? The gang'll be there,  in the section... Thanks. Appreciate  it. See you.
He hangs up, returns to the table and starts to shuffle t cards in his own spectacular way. (TIME LAPSE)
A game is in progress between the Cardinals and another  National League club. The batter at the plate connects fo long one. CAMERA FOLLOWS the flight of the ball.

They are making their way to meet their friends in the se they prefer. They stop to watch the ball as the fans arou them rise to their feet. The section they have just reach is in the sun, overlooking the outfield.
An outfielder races back and makes a difficult catch.

They start on their way again. CAMERA PANS ahead of them a group consisting of Hoban; HOBAN'S WOMAN, still sexy in her forties; PIG, whose name could derive with equal  justification from either his looks or his manners; and S who talks colloquial American with a Central European acc The group as a whole is notable because its members have risen to their feet with everyone else, because all the m are basking in the sun with their shirts off, because the view the action on the field with detachment, and because nevertheless, they are constantly placing bets on details the game. Now, as people around them resume their seats,  Sokal is able to confirm that the fly ball has been caugh
(to Hoban) You owe me two fish on the out, plus  three on the inning, minus two on no  strikeouts so far.
The Kid and Melba join them.
Hiya, Kid. Getting yourself in shape  for The Man? (to Melba) Shooter still on the job?
Where's Christian?
(in a whisper) Lay off that.
What'd she do, take off? So did mine.  Don't lose no sweat, Kid, there's  plenty more where they came from.  All shapes and sizes.
Hi, Hoban. Sokal. Pig.
He and Melba sit down.
(to Sokal) Boyer. One to two on the sacrifice.
Five to three, I'll give you. Two- fifty against one-fifty.
Mark it.
I figure they'll walk him. Fill up  first.
Not with who's coming up. I'll take  the same odds.
While he is talking, Melba unbuttons his shirt.
Get some of this sun.
(to The Kid) Mark it.
(to Melba) Guess I will.
He takes his shirt off. Melba finds some suntan lotion in her bag, and applies it to her face and arms, her eyes ra straying from The Kid.
Bunting, Sokal.
The bunt is fielded by the first baseman, who throws to s for the out. There is no play at first.
So they pitched to him. I still win.
(to Kid) Everybody been on the phone to  everybody about coming to watch you  and Lancey. Big Spriigi, Yeller to  N'Orleans, Old Lady Fingers. They're  all coming.
(to Kid) Let me give you some of this. Keep  you from burning.
I don't think --
Can't hurt you.
Without waiting for his approval, she goes ahead and spre the lotion on his skin, painstakingly, as if she were app paint to canvas, working it in, one area at a time, with fingertips.
(to Sokal) Chance to invest your profits. Bet  you an even fin he make first.
(looking toward plate) Who we got -- Warwick? You got  yourself a bet, pal.

The men concentrate their attention on the diamond. CAMER MOVES IN to Melba's fingers playing across The Kid's midr From the field comes the sharp CRACK of a bat against a b followed by a SHOUT from the crowd. CAMERA PANS UP to the faces of Melba and The Kid as he looks at her and she mee his gaze with inviting eyes.
Not your day, Hoban. (calling to a vendor) Hey, beer!
(softly) Mais tu es charmant --
With the same look of invitation in her eyes.
Charmant. Come here, please.

CAMERA PULLS BACK. Wearing the same clothes as at the bal park, she is sitting in a chair with her legs tucked unde her. The Kid is sitting on a straight chair at a table on which he has a cup of coffee. They are alone in the apart
Any special reason?
Me. I'm special.
He stands up but doesn't move toward her.
Sure you are. You're The Shooter's  woman.
Right. And maybe I'll go on being  The Shooter's Woman, even after you  and I have had our little romp. What  do you think about that?
First place, Old Shooter'll come  barging through that door any minute.  He said they were winding it up.
No barging. He doesn't have his key  with him. (stands up) Have to buzz from downstairs. (moves toward him  provocatively) So we can treat ourselves to a little  sample of things to come.
The Kid stays where he is as she comes up against him.
Also it don't mean anything to you,  you're Christian's friend?
Honey, she lost her franchise the  minute she got on that bus. You know  that. (her arms around him) I have a shaky sense of security,  Kid. Don't make me feel unwanted.
He kisses her and lets himself enjoy it for a while, then pulls away.
No good?
You know damn well how good it was.  Where's a pack of cards?
What do we need cards for?
Gin or casino, you name it. All I  know is we're switching to another  indoor sport.

The poker game is over. Two of the Wealthy Types have alr departed; one is finishing a drink on the way out; anothe is putting his winnings into his wallet; a third is writi out a check. Lancey and The Shooter still sit at the tabl in f.g.
Lady Fingers'll want to come, I bet,  and she's right on the edge of her  stake. She could spell me dealing.
Sure, sure. Haven't seen the dear  old bitch in fifteen years.
Well, that's it, then. Monday night,  Room Three-Eleven at the Dorset Hotel.  And may the best man win.
Yes, that's how it usually comes out  in the long run. You think this boy  is going to give me trouble, Shooter?
Yeah, he's going to give you trouble.
I don't want it to be one of those  marathon games. Not any more.
Like the session with The Portugee  at Jolly's in Omaha. Remember?
Sure, sure. Longest game I ever played  though, I was a kid on my way to the  Klondike gold rush. At Soapy Smith's  in Skagway. Four nights and three  days.
You win?

Depends how you look at it. When we  wound up, the Yukon River had frozen  over and you couldn't get through to  Dawson City till the following June.  Made myself a Hundred and fifty bucks  and missed the gold rush.
You been around a long time.
That is undeniably true. But it  doesn't mean I'm ready to retire.  How old is this boy of yours?
Twenty-six, twenty-eight, something  like that.
Well, now, makes me feel a whole lot  better, knowing that. I was thirty- six when I sliced up Eddie the Dude.  This Kid of yours is just going to  have to wait a few years.

He is standing by an elevator in f.g. keeping watch on a of room doors including the site of the poker game. FELIX an impressive physical specimen whose capacity for brutal is masked by a quiet, deferential manner. When he sees a  door open, he moves so as to be out of The Shooter's sigh as the latter comes toward him. It isn't until The Shoote rounds the corner in f.g. and presses the button for the  elevator that Felix makes his presence known.
Excuse me, Mr. Shooter, sir, but Mr.  Schlaegel asked me to remind you how  eager he was to see you.
The doors of the elevator open. Felix yields precedence t The Shooter and they enter it. The doors close.
An elevator opens, and The Shooter and Felix come out.
I ought to call my woman.
Yes, of course. They always like to  know it if you're going to be late  for supper.
CAMERA MOVES with them as The Shooter leads the way to a of telephone booths and enters one.
They are sitting at the table in a game of casino. She pl an ace from her hand, adds a seven from the board, and la them both on top of a three-card pile.
Still building eights.
Thanks for putting it together for  me.
He plays an eight and takes in the whole pile.
It's not my game.
The telephone RINGS. She stands up.
Want to know what is?
CAMERA FOLLOWS her to the phone. She picks it up.
(into phone) Hello -- Oh, hi, sugar -- why not?
She reaches a hand around to the back of her neck, fiddle with her dress a moment, then beckons in The Kid's direct
He doesn't understand what she wants but he gets up and c to her obligingly, CAMERA MOVING with him.
(into phone) What's the switch?

She points to the hook-and-eye fastener at the top of the zipper that runs down the back of her dress. The Kid  pantomimes the question "What for?" but she just wiggles finger impatiently at the fastener while speaking into th phone.
(into phone) Whose idea was that?

The Kid still doesn't know what she has in mind but it se easier to humor her than not. He unfastens the hook. Melb smiles her thanks and, to his consternation, reaches back and pulls the zipper all the way down. She places her han over the mouth-piece of the phone.
(to Kid) He's not coming home now.
She steps out of the dress.
(into phone) Whatever you say, Shooter man.
(into phone) Explain to The Kid, will you?
Melba in her bra and panties, snuggles against The Kid.
(into phone) He'll understand.
(into phone) Tell him they decided to play a little  longer, and I'll call him at his  place later when the game's over...  Right. Goodbye, honey.
He hangs up the phone and emerges from the booth. CAMERA  MOVES with him as he joins Felix and they walk toward the hotel entrance.
The Kid, his policy toward this new situation still  unresolved, holds her lightly while he tries to think it aloud.
Listen, Melba --
I have to tell you first. You're  sitting down with Lancey next Monday  night.
I wish it was sooner. I wish it was  tomorrow.
Shooter'll give you all the details  later.
I don't like waiting that long.
Let's not kick a gift horse in the  teeth, sugar. We've got this time  together. Let's try to "fill each  unforgiving minute with sixty seconds  worth of distance run."
She invites a kiss and he obliges her. But there is a con force at work inside him.
Listen, what I was going to say  before, I don't want you to think  I'm being some kind of jerk or I  don't feel you'd be great to sack up  with.
Then let's cut the filibuster.
I've made dolls that were friends of  mine's wives. I figured if they were  willing, they were doing it to their  husbands, I wasn't.
Of course. Any other attitude, you're  degrading the woman. You're not  treating her as a person with a mind  of her own, but as somebody's  property.
Again she presses close to him and again he savors her fo moment.

Only thing is, it's different with  The Shooter than anybody else. He's  so straight, I got the obligation to  be straighter with him than other  people. So do you. On account of we  both owe him plenty.
I thought we just agreed that what  you and I did was strictly between  us.

Can't be. (decisively, pulling  away from her with a  pat of dismissal) Shooter's the closest thing to family  I got. It's almost like he was my  old man. Don't you see how that's  got a bearing on us?
He starts out. Melba stares after him, scarcely able to  believe what is being done to her.
Sure, it means I'm your mother.

An expensive automobile, with Felix at the wheel and The  Shooter next to him in the front seat, approaches the mai house of a lavish estate in a St. Louis suburb. It contin along the driveway past the house.
In swimming trunks, Bill is spoon-feeding a year-old BABY a highchair. Looking o.s., he waves in greeting to The  Shooter.
He walks from the parked car toward the pool, returning B salutation.

SHOOTING from behind The Shooter as he approaches the  attractive family group that includes, besides Bill and t baby, a FIVE-YEAR-OLD GIRL who is having her hair brushed after swimming by ROSANNA SCHLAEGEL, her beautiful mother family dog completes the picture. Bill continues to feed baby as he hails The Shooter.

Shooter -- very generous of you to  come on such short notice. Rosanna  you know, and I think you've met my  daughter June. (indicating baby) No point introducing you to William  the Fourth. He has a bad memory for  names.
(greeting them in  turn) Mrs. Schlaegel. How are you, June.  What's it all about, Bill?
Little something I'd like to sound  you out on. But the least I can do  is offer you a drink.
Like me to fix it, love?
Wonderful. Why don't you do a batch  of your Bloody Marys? If that's okay  with you, Shooter?
Great. Whatever.
As she goes off, Rosanna cautions June about her hair.
Just don't let it get wet again.
As soon as his wife is gone, Bill goes right to the topic doesn't want to discuss in her presence.
I've been quite busy on the telephone  since I last saw you. There's a lot  of interest all over the country in  this game with Lancey and The Kid.
Betting interest?
Jack Doyle in New York is giving  twelve to five on Lancey. Same odds  in Reno. I've taken fifty thousand  of it so far.
Fifty thousand!
I'll probably go for more but I didn't  want to rock the odds.
I knew you liked The Kid's style but  why you going in so deep?
Two reasons. First, I want to see  that smug old bastard gutted worse  than he gutted me. Second, as long  as that's going to happen, I don't  see why I shouldn't make some money  out of it.
But how can you be so sure? The Kid  could do it, we both know that, but --
"Could" isn't good enough for a man  who hates to lose money as much as I  do. He's going to need help -- from  the best man with a pack of cards  between Omaha and New Orleans.
Not a chance, Bill. You ought to  know I never ever use what I got  with the cards for nothing but tricks  and dressing up a game.
Sure, I know it. That's why you're  the man they choose to give them a  square deal. That's what makes it so  perfect. Nobody'll be looking for  it.
It's out. Out.
The great thing is they'll be so  close, The Kid won't need much. Three  or four key hands.
Understand this, Bill. I'd like for  The Kid to win, and I sure as hell  don't want to see you lose all that  money --
If I did, I'd have to collect that  twelve grand you owe me. Not myself.  My collection agents. You knew poor  Wildwood Jones, didn't you?
OK but I'm paying it off! It's comin'  in ain't it? Six grand already. (then as Bill just  looks at him) Bill, you got to listen to me --!
No, I don't. It's quite the other  way around. You have some delusion  you're a free agent, but you're not.  I own you.
For God's sake --!

Shut up. I'll cross the twelve off  the books and give you ten thousand  dollars in cash. And you can tell  The Kid if he needs more of a stake,  I'll put it up. (looks o.s. and smiles) Marvelous. Here's Rosanna with what  you need.
CAMERA MOVES to include Rosanna carrying a tray with glas and a pitcher full of Bloody Marys.
-- for that dry feeling on the roof  of your mouth.
It is raining dismally.

He is lying on one half of the bed, with the covers throw back, his hands clasped behind his head, wearing pajama  bottoms. He turns his head and stares at the white expans of unoccupied bed. (TIME LAPSE)
The weather is clear as The Kid wanders idly along a  residential street of well-kept nineteenth century buildi (TIME LAPSE)

He is drinking a bottle of beer slowly. CAMERA PANS to an bar stool where a customer is having his shoes shined by NEGRO BOY who slaps his rag against the shoes with a fine sense of rhythm. Finished, he collects his dime and nicke tip, and moves to The Kid.
Shine them up for you sir?
No, thanks.
Fetch you a newspaper maybe?
No.
How about a singy-song then? I play  good.
Play what?

The Boy takes out a tobacco can with the lid torn off and the top flattened down and shakes it, producing a sound l the rustle of dry leaves. Then he produces a similar can  that makes a rattling noise when he shakes it.
Dry corn in this one. Blue shale  stone from the river in this one.  You ready?
Yes, I'm ready.
The Boy looks at the BARTENDER, who has moved closer to s what's going on.
(to bartender) You ready?
Hell, I'm ready for anything.

The Boy stands perfectly still for a few seconds, then be to shake the can with corn in it. After a bit he brings i the shale stone can with the other hand to chord and acce the rustle of the first can. At the same time he begins to sing a simple song in a pur delicate voice. It is catfish music created on the spot a sounds strangely like the idle tunes Christian likes to h
(when the song is  over) Thank you very much. That was nice.  Where did you learn to do that?
I picked it up from Herman.
Who is Herman?
My friend I pick it up from.
Is he a good friend?
I don't know 'bout that suh. He just  a frien' who teach me some things.
Well, I don't want a shine, but here's  fifteen cents.
Thank you, sir.
And here's another dime for you,  fella.
He rings up a NO SALE and flips a dime to The Boy, who is astonished and then worried by this munificence. Suddenly grabs his tobacco cans and his shoe-shine kit, and runs o into the street.
Nice little colored kid.
(mostly to himself) -- Yeah. (TIME LAPSE)
JANSEN, a masseur, is at work loosening up The Kid's neck and shoulders.
Monday night, uh, Kid?
Monday night.
I sprung for some of the action. A  yard and a half of that five-to-two.
Thanks, Jansen. (in pain) Hey!
We got to get you loosened up. I  never felt you this tight. (TIME LAPSE)
He is in the middle of a call.
(into phone) Just tell The Shooter I'll be there  on the dot Monday night.
(over the phone) And until then?
He doesn't have to know.
(into phone) I'm not asking for him.

He hangs up the phone, rather than continue the discussio CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he comes out of the booth, picks up small duffel bag, and walks to the door that leads to the busses. He goes out into the night and gets into a bus. (TIME LAPSE)
A bus drives along a main road in the Ozarks, heading tow CAMERA. As it comes close, the name of its destination:  "FAYETTEVILLE" can be read.

The bus stops momentarily at a small cluster of buildings around an intersection. The Kid is the only passenger to off here. As the bus continues on its way, he goes to an  attendant in a gas station on one corner, and asks a ques Referred to a general store and post office on another co he crosses and goes into it. The STOREKEEPER comes back  outside with him to point out the route to where he wants go. It is along a dirt road that winds uphill behind the  store. The Kid starts up the road. (TIME LAPSE)

The Kid reaches the summit of the hill directly behind th crossroads, and looks down into the valley between this h and the next one. He starts down an even narrower road le to a little farm on a hillock in the valley. It consists a modest cabin, a single barn, a fenced cow pasture, and few cultivated fields. (TIME LAPSE)

Christian comes around a curve in a path on one side of t house, carrying two five-gallon milk cans slung in a yoke over her shoulder. A little dog YAPS and runs from the fr door of the house to the front gate. She looks in that  direction and CAMERA MOVES to include The Kid as he unlat the gate and walks toward her. After a moment's hesitatio she moves to meet him, gliding on her bare feet to keep t water in the cans from slopping out.
Hello, Kid.
Can I help you with those?
Taking if off is harder than taking  it on in.
She turns toward the side of the house and walks to the  kitchen door. The Kid follows.
How's The Shooter?
Fine.
You haven't played yet?
Monday.

location: CHRISTIAN, THE KID AND MRS. CRAIGI

text: MRS. CRAIGIE, Christian's mother, opens the door for them giving The Kid a sharp, appraising glance.
This is Eric, Mama. He's come to see  me.
How do, Eric.

Christian crosses to the drain sink near the pump and tur her back. Mrs. Craigie lifts the cans off the yoke on to drain board. She and Christian each take a can and pour t water from it to prime the pump.
We lost suction on the pump right in  the middle of canning.
The Kid looks at the stove with a couple of large steamin pots on it, and the table alongside with a half-dozen ham of green beans.
There's coffee. And sour ham and  bread in the warmer, if you're hungry  Eric.
As soon as they are finished with the pump, Mrs. Craigie Christian turn to the table, where they begin to snip ste and cut beans before putting them into the pots on the st
You know anything about canning, you  know we can't stop now. If we'd been  looking for company, we never would  have started.
Spring beans, you have to cook them  fast. But you find yourself some  breakfast.
I'm all right. Bus stopped for  doughnuts and coffee.
You can stay with us tonight and  still make it back to St. Lou on the  Sunday schedule by about midnight. I  told Mama and Papa about The Man.  And all.
Where is Mr. Craigie?
To the barn. Why don't you go down  and introduce yourself? Christian  and me'll be at this another hour or  two.
I think I will. I think I'd like  that. (to Christian) Okay?
Sure. And I'll see you a little later  on. (then, as he starts  out) Papa don't know everything. About  you and me.
The Kid looks quickly at her and then at Mrs. Craigie, wh keeps her gaze fixed on the beans.

He is pitching manure from all over the cow-lot into a pi banked against the side of the barn, working a long-handl shovel with practised ease. He looks o.s. and sees The Ki approaching but continues his work as The Kid enters the  SHOT. Nor does he stop shoveling while they are talking,  except at moments of particular significance to him.
Hello.
How do you do, Mr. Craigie. I'm Eric  Stoner.
Christian's Eric.
That's right.
You seen her?
She's helping her mother can.
You minding to marry Christian?
The Kid looks at him a long moment then --
You got any objections if I do, or  if I don't?
Craigie takes a couple of steps toward The Kid, his boots sucking in the muddy ground.
Son, that's what I call a sharp  answer.
It was what I call a sharp question.
We don't know much about you,  Christian's mother and me.
I'm what's known as a three-river  man. Which just means I go around  playing stud poker wherever I can  find the kind of action I'm looking  for.
You met Christian when she was working  to Hot Springs?
Yeah. I was playing in this game in  the hotel and she was a waitress in  the coffee shop. We went out. I told  her I thought she could get a better  job in St. Louis.
Now how did you happen to tell her  that? Maybe you run some kind of  employment service on the side?
I said it because I wanted her in  St. Louis. Anyway, she made it there  and she called me and we been seeing  each other ever since.
Living together?
The Kid takes his time before deciding how to answer this one.
Yeah, living together.
How come she come home now? She going  to have a baby?
Not that I know of.
You two have a fight?
No.
She must have had a reason.
Think so? Well, you've known her  longer than me. (then) Look, Mr. Craigie, let me and  Christian find out a few things then  maybe I won't have to answer your  questions.
I never run across anybody like you.  I guess I don't understand gamblers.
That's all right. I don't understand  farmers.
You say things that sound smart  alecky. But I'm not sure if they  really are smart alecky.
Well I can't take into account what  somebody's going to feel every time  I say something.
Are you a believer?
In some things.
I mean in God.
That's a tough one. I don't disbelieve  in Him, but I couldn't say I believed  in Him either. I guess I just never  paid Him much mind. Didn't seem  important.
God not important?
I don't mean what He does isn't  important -- if He exists. I mean  it's not important to me whether He  exists or not.
Christian was raised in a Christian  home.
Is that so? I didn't know --- (then) I'm not aware of the difference. (pause) I'm not asking permission to marry  Christian, you know.
I know.
If I was, the only person I'd be  asking it from is her.
(after a moment) Who is this fella Christian says  you're going to play that's so  important?
He's the king of the stud poker  players.
And you're going to play him.
Yes.
Are you any good?
I'm this good. The Man has got to  play me.
What happens if he don't?
Then I'm The Man.
That important to you?
I been trying to figure that out  ever since I set it up.
You playing because of money?
(after a moment) Not really.
Christian said you never was much  worried about money -- I been worried  about money most of my life -- up  until I figured out it wasn't so  important.
No, it's necessary, but it isn't so  important.
Well how come you want to play this  King fella?
Ambition -- maybe security, like  that.
Is it aspiration to be the King or  just uncertainty about the future?
I ain't looking for security if that's  what you mean.
Not trying to lock something up tight  and nail it down?
That would figure into it. But that  isn't all of it. -- It's important  to me.
Now son which is more important to  you, this king business or Christian?
If you got the guts to ask that  question, Mr. Craigie, I guess I got  the guts to answer it. Christian, if  you came right down to it, is not as  important as doing what I have to  do.
Craigie has finished piling the manure. He puts away his  shovel.
Well son, I had to know.
Know what?

There never was a man worth a damn,  to my mind, who let his woman stand  in the way of the thing he had to  do. (then) I got to go now -- see what I can do  for a sick heifer. Why don't you  take Christian, when her Mama lets  go of her, and tell her I said you  should go to the old spring. It's a  good place.
Thanks. I'll tell her.
Craigie walks away. (TIME LAPSE)
It is a small shack against a rocky bluff. CAMERA PANS  Christian and The Kid as they come down the path and ente
It stays warm all winter.
CAMERA MOVES to reveal Christian and The Kid, who are in pool without clothes, treading water.
Papa's mama used to bring her wash  up here.
We liable to draw an audience?
Don't worry. It's on our land --  Nobody uses it.

She starts to swim, CAMERA MOVING with her upper back as reaches the side of the pool and pulls herself on to the  bank, lying on her stomach. The Kid joins her, first draw himself up on his stomach alongside her, then turning on back to look through the slats at the sun.
You must have said something to Papa  gave him the picture on us in St.  Lou. Else he never would have spoke  to you about this place.
I told him on account of he already  knew. Never any sense feeding a man  a lie he's not going to believe.
Even if he did know, I'm glad you  told him.
She raises herself up so that she is directly above him.
(in mock protest) Hey, you're all wet!
So are you, foolish. (TIME LAPSE)

The two men are sitting just outside the kitchen, where M Craigie and Christian are pasting labels on the mason jar they filled earlier. The paste and some of the jars are j inside an open window on a shelf behind the men's heads. light comes from a kerosene lamp inside.
Let me get this straight in my head.  Cards is all a matter of luck, who  gets dealt the best ones.

The Kid stands up and selects six playing cards from a de in his pocket. During the next few lines he uses the past on the shelf to stick together three pairs of them so as form three double-thick cards. One of these has two faces another two backs, and the third a back and a face.
So when one of you professional  gamblers sits down with a bunch of  your -- what do you call them --  customers, clients?
The technical term is "suckers." Or  "marks."
Their chance of winning is just as  good as yours, except if you got a  way to control it, who gets what  cards. Right?
Not right. That's cheating and it's  not any part of what we're talking  about.
Then how do you win?
I'll show you.
He displays his three cards.
You see one of these cards is white  on both sides, one is red on both  sides, and the other is white on one  side, red on the other.
What about it?
The Kid lifts a straw hat off a peg on the porch wall.
This. I put the three cards in a hat  and shake them up, and then I ask  you to draw one card out blind. Put  it face down on the table so neither  of us can see the bottom side.
Craigie does as instructed. The ensuing dialogue assumes card he picks is red on top; if it's white the words "red and "white" will be reversed in the dialogue.

Okay, red on top. That eliminates  the all-white card, right. So the  card you've picked is one of two --  the all-red or the red-and-white.  One out of two is an even chance, an  even-money proposition. Right -- you  follow me?
I think so.
So if I said I'll bet you a dollar  to seventy-five cents the other side  of that card is red, you'd take the  bet wouldn't you?
Seems like. Yeah.
And that answer makes you a sucker.  Because the odds are two to one, the  other side of that card is red, and  I ought to be offering you a dollar  to fifty cents instead of seventy- five.
But if there are just the two  possibilities.

There are three possibilities. (indicating card on  table) That can be the red side of the red- and-white card, or it can be either  side of the all-red card. In two  cases out of three the other side is  red. And I'd win the bet from you  two out of every three times we made  it.
(dubiously) You would?
Sure. It's obvious when I explain  it, isn't it?
Reckon so. Except if there's only  two things that the bottom side can  be, red or white --

Take my word for it -- the odds are  two to one. And knowing that is the  difference between your gambling man  and your sucker. Not who gets the  better cards but who knows what the  proper odds are. In a poker game  there can be a million different  situations, each with a different  set of odds to figure. The man who  ends up winners is the man who knows  when to bet and how much...
The sucker is still took advantage  of, isn't he? The gambler knows  something he don't know.

Sure -- like if you grow better corn  or raise a cow that gives more milk  than the other guy's. Or two business  men are in competition, or two lawyers  are up against each other in a  courtroom. Whatever your line is,  the one who wins out is the one who  knows his job better.
Seems like there should be something  else to it --
There is -- Making the man you're  playing against think he's got the  best hand -- and making him pay to  find out.
He is lying on a cot in the darkness, next to the big woo burning stove. Christian enters the SHOT and slips under covers with him.
I can't stay long. Papa'll be getting  up to milk.
I'm the one can't stay. I got to  head for that bus.
Why did you come, Kid?
Well, hell, I don't know. I had kind  of a rough time after you left.
Rough how?
Tuesday there was a ball game, but  then the Cardinals went on the road.  I never known time to drag so; I was  all torn apart --
Because of the poker game coming up?
That's how I read it, but I was  reading it wrong. It wasn't Lancey  or the game that was chewing at my  insides --
What else is there could give you  such a bad time?
I finally figured it. I located where  the trouble was. It was you.
She is genuinely surprised at this and at first a bit  dismayed. But her more considered reaction is one of plea
Oh, --
She kisses him.
When you talk about doing something  besides poker if I get to be The  Man, you don't mean pass up the chance  to make some dough from it for a  while?
I sure don't. I told Papa, wherever  money comes from, it feels the same  when you spend it.
You were going to do some thinking  down here.
I done some.
Then they both react as Craigie can be heard getting up.
I'll be back after the game Christian --  You wait here for me and I'll let  you know.
All right Eric -- Good luck Monday.
She gives him a quick kiss and stands up.
I got that made now. You said it  right. My time's come. (TIME LAPSE)
The sun hasn't risen yet as The Kid boards the bus for St Louis outside the general store.
The Kid's bus crossing the endless plain in the afternoon sun.
The clock above the loading platform says it is a little  after two in the morning as the bus pulls up, and The Kid groggy from the long ride, gets out.

He enters wearily, goes straight into the bedroom and  collapses on the bed. After a moment he summons the energ to loosen his shoelaces and kick his shoes off. But that  completes his preparations for sleep.
The Shooter is awake because he can't sleep, and Melba is awake because she is trying to persuade him to do what sh considers prudent. He sighs deeply as she solicitously po him a cup of coffee.
Twenty-five years I been building a  reputation.
Handle this thing right and your  reputation will be better than ever.

Lancey is also awake, confronting a row of medicine bottl He finishes laying out an assortment of four different pi and capsules, pours himself a glass of hot milk from a ca and proceeds to take the pills one at a time, with a sip milk after each. (TIME LAPSE)

The Kid, looking completely refreshed, is readying himsel for the game. He has chosen casual, comfortable clothes, now he collects three items to take with him: a large bot of mouthwash, a green sun-vizor, and finally, his stake.  When he withdraws the money from the dresser drawer, we c see the pile has increased in size. The Kid finds an enve to put it in, and he is ready to go. He starts out but in the middle of the kitchen he stops to look at his watch. is too early. He crosses to the stove, pours himself a cu of coffee, and sits down to drink it.

Lancey has decided on a change of costume from his last g and this time he goes for the old-fashioned velvet smokin jacket and silk foulard. Over this he puts on a light  overcoat. Then he assembles medicines, toilet articles an money, putting them all into a small satchel. Finally, he puts on his hat and goes to the door.
We follow Lancey's progress as far as the elevator.
Melba and Shooter have finished dressing, and he waits by the door while she does the inevitable last-minute things her makeup.
I made up my mind to this. I ain't  going to give him any help till he  needs it.
I'm glad you're taking a stand.
Hey, what if he starts off lucky and  stays ahead of the game the whole  way. It could happen, you know.
You'll make it happen, Baby. I've  got faith in you --
The hands are at 7:25.
The Kid is looking at the clock tower.
Once more around the square.

The taxi drives away from CAMERA following The Kid's  instruction. CAMERA PANS to the front of the Dorset Hotel which they have just passed. It is fifty years old or mor no longer elegant but still respectable.
He is standing at ease among old friends, sipping a creme menthe frappe.
It's a friendly town, St. Louis.  I've always said that.

CAMERA MOVES to take in the people around him, one after  another. The Shooter is there, and Pig and Sokal and Hoba and Melba and Hoban's woman and a couple of other women w main attributes are physical, and Bill Schlaegel. Out of  town representatives include LADY FINGERS, who is about f down on her luck but still cheerful and remarkably energe and YELLER, a light-skinned Negro who has achieved statur in what is mainly a white man's world, through diplomacy a quick wit. The room is the large living-room of a once  splendid suite; there are enough chairs and couches aroun the walls to accommodate a good many spectators, while th middle of the room has been cleared for a round table wit seven chairs.
We ain't seen much of you though,  last seven, eight years.
Climate, Shooter. In my declining  years, I spend more and more time in  Florida and the Gulf Coast.
Lot of folks been figuring another  reason you was keeping clear of the  three rivers.
What reason is that, Lady Fingers?
Cincinnati Kid. (laughs) That the way it is, Lancey? You been  scared of The Kid?
Should I be scared of him?

Damn right you should! I'm telling  you, that boy going to make your  stomach ulcer bleed before the night  is out. He's close to murder. I seen  him give a fella the shakes so bad  on a fourth card, it took a pint of  corn liquor to settle him down.
Thanks for the warning.
Lancey notices that most of the people around him have tu to look at the doorway. He glances in the same direction a casual sort of way.
He saunters toward Lancey. Almost everyone greets him, an he responds to as many as he can. Melba intercepts him.
Mow the man down, sugar pie, make it  quick and bloody. Been too many lean  years for all of us.
I intend to take Shooter right along  with Lancey.
I'm not talking about the old Shooter.  He's been factory rebuilt. A new  spirit dwelleth in him, and his gaze  is on distant hills.
The Kid would like these cryptic words explained, but Lad Fingers descends on him.
So you showed up after all. You're a  braver boy than I thought, so much  the worse for you.
You think I'll be sorry I come?

Bound to. That Lancey ain't human,  he's one of them barracuda fish.  He's liable to bleed to death, right  on a flush hand before he give up to  you. I seen him gut a fella so bad,  the fella quit and got up and spit  red in the john and went square.
The Kid sees Lancey approaching, and turns to him.
Hello, Kid. Pleasure to know you.
Lancey. I been looking forward a  long time.
Sure, sure. You seem to know about  everybody. Yeller from New Orleans?
What do you say, Yeller? Still feeling  salty with me?
Forgiven long since. (to Lancey) We had a little jurisdictional  dispute.
I hustled a couple of boys, right in  his territory.
So I tried to tell him our rules  down there. Colored marks are for  colored hustlers.
And I tried to tell him how I got no  prejudice. When I'm on the edge of  my stake, I hustle anybody at all,  regardless of race, creed or color.  Anybody at all.
Including my girl.
Hell, I figured I was doin' you a  favor.
You did.
Suddenly they both laugh over a private memory and shake  hands, obviously old friends.
(to Lancey) Did you know Old Cottonhead died?
No, I hadn't heard.
Heart give out in a high-low game.
(turning to The Kid) How you feel, Kid?
Great. You?
The best. You think maybe we ought  to see if we can stir up some action?
Whatever you say, Lancey. You're the -- (correcting himself) You're our guest in this town.
Well, I'm kind of in the mood to  play a little cards.
I think we ought to be able to get a  game together in this crowd.
But first you take a look at things --  make sure everything's the way you  want it. I already been around.
Thanks. I'll do that.
He turns toward the center of the room. The Shooter follo him.

The old, solidly built wooden table has been covered with white linen cloth on top of a blanket. The cloth is tied  down under the rim so that the surface of the table is fl tight and cushioned by the blanket. The Kid presses his  fingers into it to test these factors.
It's an old table. Everything's pretty  old in this hotel.
It's solid, that's what counts. And  you got the top fixed perfect.
Lancey comes into the SHOT behind them.
Light all right for you?
Two hundred watt bulb.
Fine, excellent. Okay with you?
Sure, sure. Shooter's set us up just  great.
Sure has.
Thank you, gents. Tried to do the  best I could. (looks from one to  the other) Cards?
Why not?
Good a time as any.
(calling) Hoban! Okay! (to Kid and Lancey) You both know Joe Hoban. He's a draw  poker man, but clean and straight as  they come.
Hoban comes into the SHOT with a dispatch case, which he  sets on the table. He unlocks it with a key and turns it  upside down. Thirty sealed decks of cards spill on the ta

They come from the St. Louis Bridge  Club, but they're poker size cards.  They been bonded by the club steward  and I seen him take them out of the  safe. Shooter, Lady Fingers and me  pick them up and come straight here  with them.
Hoban's selling them to us at five  dollars a pack, with the usual  guarantee. If it's proved any deck  is spooked, he pays off the losers.
St. Louis Bridge Club, eh? Steward  still that old yard bird Okra?
(disturbed) That's him.
(not noticing; to Kid) Old stud man, Okra.
I don't know him.
Quite a character. Quite a character.
(anxiously) Nobody heard from me what the cards  were for, Kid.
There is a quick exchange of glances all around as the ot three realize what the imaginary suspicion is behind Hoba defensive reaction.
(to Kid) Been ten years since I seen or spoke  to Old Okra.
'Kay, fine. Don't worry about it,  Lancey. Who's sitting down with us,  Shooter?
Four of us. Me, Pig, Yeller and Doc  Sokal. If that's all right with you  both?
'Kay, fine.
Sure, sure. (to Kid) Shall we have a look at the decks?

with the pile of decks and the empty dispatch case on the table in front of them. They start checking the decks one one, each putting the ones he has covered in a pile for t other's consideration. They examine the seals and the  cellophane visually, and they also sniff both ends for th odor of a hot iron. By the time they are through with thi process; The Kid has found three decks he isn't satisfied with, and Lancy two. The Kid passes his three rejects to  Lancey, who tosses them back into the dispatch case witho looking at them. Then Lancey tries to submit his two to T Kid, but The Kid waves them away, and Lancey throws them, too, into the case.
Well, Kid, what's your game?

CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the other four players, who  have come up to the table, still not taking chairs until  Lancey and The Kid have chosen theirs. Though Lancey's  question is purely ritualistic, they look to The Kid for reply.
I don't mind stud poker if that's  okay with you.
I got no objections to stud. (to the others) Gentlemen?
Consulting the others is a formality, but all four of the Yeller, Shooter, Pig and Sokal -- nod or grunt or otherwi indicate assent.
across the room, he is indicating to The Shooter that he' like a word with him before play begins.
He detaches himself from the group and sidles inconspicuo over to Bill.
Tell The Kid I have a suite on the  fifth floor. He can drop up during  the breaks. Bedroom all for him any  time he wants a nap.
That's thoughtful of you, Bill.
I'm a thoughtful man. I hope you  are.
The Kid gestures to Lancey to choose his seat. Lancey  acknowledges the courtesy, glances at the window and pick himself a chair facing away from it.
Privilege of age. Can't take the  glare of the morning sun in my eyes.

The Kid, following protocol, moves to a seat directly acr from Lancey's. The Shooter takes his place at the table  halfway between The Kid and Lancey, and pulls the twenty- five eligible packs of cards to him.
You want to have the usual brandy  and coffee on hand, Kid? Anything  special for you, Lancey?
Why, yes, Shooter. Creme de menthe  frappe. Green.

(glances around) You got that, Hoban? (to the table) Gentlemen, if there are no objections,  I'm the dealer. These rooms have  been contracted for, and there will  be an ante of ten dollars per chair,  per day. During the breaks for me,  Old Lady Fingers has agreed to deal,  but she don't care to be a player --
Do too care!
CAMERA PANS to reveal Lady Fingers as she steps from amon the spectators to a place behind Lancey.
Can't afford to play, that's the  real truth. Had a bad year and I'm  way over my edge.
Lady Fingers will get three dollars  an hour from the ante, plus her room  and food, and a five-minute break  every hour. Gents?
Fine, Shooter man.
'Kay with us.

If you don't see me when you need  me, call room three-oh-eight. (taps Lancey's shoulder) You know who else ain't with us no  more? Miriam, widow used to run the  kitchen game to South Chi. Lost two  month's Relief at blackjack, coal  dealer cut her credit, and she froze  in her bed.

The Kid has taken his roll from his pocket and is countin it out rapidly. The other players watch, interested to se how much he is putting out. After counting out one stack thirty hundreds, he distributes the rest in stacks of  twenties, tens and fives, folding each bill over once as  protection against picking up more than one at a time.
Gentlemen, this is a game of five- card stud poker. There is no limit.  A dead man has one half hour to raise  his roll outside and get back in the  game.
The Kid has completed his count.
He takes the money from his satchel.
Five grand? Nice, tidy sum. I'll put  out the same.
CAMERA PANS to Yeller.
I swear I don't know what I'm doing  sitting down with you titans, but  maybe it's worth putting up five  thousand for the educational value.
CAMERA PANS to Pig as he brings out a roll and drops it  casually in front of him.
I'll play with what I have in my  pocket till I have to send out for  more. Twenty-seven, twenty-eight  hundred, I don't know.
CAMERA PANS past The Kid to Sokal, who is counting out bi from an impressive roll.
Five G's, I'm with it. Don't mean  I'm goin' blow it all, though.
CAMERA PANS to The Shooter, who is counting out a smaller stake than anyone.
Last and certainly least --
He puts his money out without counting it, takes a deck o cards, rips the cellophane off it, takes the jokers and t them offhandedly to one side, not seeming to take aim.
Heads turn as the cards sail through the air in unison,  landing inside The Shooter's familiar hat, which is resti crown down on the mantelpiece. The spectators gape at the display of dexterity.

He begins to shuffle and all eyes are upon him, not from  suspicion but from pure admiration. He is in peak form,  shuffling six times, once for each player and then slappi the cards down before Lancey, who is to the right of him, with an empty chair in between.
He waives his privilege of cutting with a barely percepti nod.

The Shooter acknowledges the compliment with the same sor of gesture. Then he begins to deal in his magnificently  precise way, pitching each card so that it comes to a sto six inches in front of the player's money and in clear vi of everyone at the table.

With Sokal in b.g. It is notable that as The Shooter comp dealing hole cards and switches to the first up card, the is no visible difference in the motion of his hands. He c the cards as he deals them.
Seven, nine, trey, nine, ace, and  The Shooter guns up a ten. Ace bets.
Ten dollars.
Dealer folds.
Call the sawbuck.
He looks at his hole card: an ace.
I'm in.
Call.
Call.
The Shooter deals again.
King to the seven, pair of nines,  deuce to the trey, queen-nine, ace- eight.
Nines bet twenty bucks.
Each other player folds in turn. The Shooter pulls in the cards, and The Kid pulls in the seventy dollars. The Shoo shuffles and deals again.
Queen, ten, king, four, ace again,  and a king for The Shooter.
Ace bets ten dollars
King over.

They are perched on the back of a love seat at the far en of the room, with their feet on the arms. This gives them view of the table through a pair of opera glasses they sh but they are far enough from it to be able to discuss the hands freely.
Shooter won't stay on a king or an  ace if there's another one showing.
What's he have to have in the hole?
Ten or better. With no other ten  showing.
