The second round has been dealt. Sokal has a queen-eight, The Kid a pair of tens, Pig a king- seven, Lancey an ace- five. Yeller, like The Shooter, has folded on the first c The Kid makes the same bet of twenty dollars, and the oth three remaining players drop.
New deck.

Unhesitatingly, The Shooter pulls in the cards, separates them into four or five piles, and tears each pile in two. glances around, and Hoban comes up behind him. The Shoote hands him the torn-up cards and unseals another pack, goi through the same routine of throwing the jokers into his  hat. (TIME LAPSE)

It is around midnight, and there is a more settled look t the game; some of the players have removed their coats, a there is a good deal of smoke in the air. The Kid has a c of coffee by him, presumably with brandy in it; Lancey ha his frappe; Pig is drinking whiskey; the Shooter and Yell have bottles of bear. It is the end of a hand. With about six hundred dollars in the pot, Pig, who has been called, turns over his hole card triumphantly.
Aces over eights. (waits for a challenge,  but the others turn  their cards) Thank you, gents. (as he pulls in money,  to Yeller) Be a laugh if the two champs ended  up cleaned.
He barely notices Pig's remark.

He barely notices Lancey's reaction to Pig's remark. CAMERA MOVES among the spectators, who also have a more  settled look about them. There is a bar, attended by a  uniformed HOTEL BELLMAN, and most of the people are drink We see in passing a couple go through the door to the bed and close it behind them. CAMERA HOLDS on the love seat a Bill rejoin Hoban on their perch.
Any action?
(shrugs) What do you expect first five or six  hours?
Still feeling each other out?
Pig's ahead about a grand, Shooter  maybe three hundred.
Sokal gets a nine of clubs, The Kid a six, Pig a queen, Y a king, Lancey a jack, and The Shooter a four.
King bets.
CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the players. There is less oral accompaniment to the betting now.
King says twenty.
Lancey calls, Shooter drops, Sokal calls, The Kid drops.
In for twenty.
(dealing) To the nine a ten, to the queen a  seven, to the king a jack, and to  the jack a jack.
Pair of jacks will venture a hundred  dollars.
(who has the nine and  ten of clubs showing) I'm in.
(after studying the  board) Up two hundred dollars.
(folding) Leave it to the rich folk.
Lancey could be laying for him with  three jacks.
Pig don't think so.
Call the two hundred.
Lancey puts in his money and so does Sokal.
I'm sticking.
Shooter deals another round: an eight of clubs to Sokal, second seven to Pig, a ten to Lancey.
Possible straight flush, pair of  sevens. Pair of jacks are still high.
Check to the sevens.
Likewise.
(trying to be casual) Bet the size of the pot. Nine hundred  and eighty dollars.
In for nine eighty.
I'll play.
What's with Lancey? I thought he'd  raise with three jacks or drop with  two pair.
He probably thinks Pig's faking the  queens. Anyhow, Doc's liable take  them both with a straight or a flush.
There is a good deal of suspense hanging on each card as Shooter deals. Sokal gets a five of diamonds, and his  disappointment is too great to conceal.
Busted, no flush, no straight. Pair  of sevens with a queen gets a nine.  To the pair of jacks, a trey.
(counting his money,  trying to be calm) Pair of sevens will bet whatever I  got here. Twenty-four hundred bucks.
I'll call your twenty-four hundred --
He watches Lancey, puzzled; this isn't what he had expect
-- and raise you whatever I have  left.
The Kid relaxes; this is more the way he figured it.
Lancey is completely calm. Pig is shattered, his whole wo suddenly blown apart.
Comes to fourteen hundred fifty  dollars, Pig. Don't imagine you'll  have any problem promoting that much  in half an hour -- plus whatever you  care to raise me.
All eyes are on Pig, which doesn't make it any easier for him. He just sits there, his hands shaking.
Fourteen fifty to the queens. You  want to take your half hour, Pig?
There is another long moment before Pig flips over his up cards.
No, I'm out. Out of the game.

He looks at Lancey with malevolence. Lancey turns over hi up cards and tosses them in front of The Shooter. Pig sud lunges toward the cards, wanting a look at Lancey's hole  card, but Lancey is too quick for him and pushes the card into the pack The Shooter is assembling.
(to Pig) You Tap City?

Pig is suffering, weighing the advantages and disadvantag of making the dread admission. Finally he nods. The Shoot takes a ten dollar bill from his own stake, and the other four remaining players each add a ten. The Shooter pushes the money toward Pig.
I got a woman.
I thought you and Hilda were quits.
We're back.
The other players look at The Shooter to see if he is goi to accept this statement at face value. He nods, that he  does, and each man contributes another ten. The Shooter p the second fifty to Pig.
See you around, Pig.
(ad lib) So long, Pig -- See you -- 'Night.
(getting up) So long.
CAMERA FOLLOWS him to the door. The spectators make room him, no one saying anything. At the door, Pig turns back his valedictory gesture.
Good luck -- Kid.
He goes out.
He has been rearranging his money, but Pig's words make h head jerk up and toward the door. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal the other players, who react dismay to the breach of form.
He shouldn't have said that. Not  after taking Tap City from the table.
His woman's been giving him a rough  time. Wants him to quit and go square.
At his age? Crazy.
He wants to wish anybody luck, doesn't  bother me. Personally, I don't figure  The Kid needs it.
Thanks, Lancey.
With that, the tension is gone. But just to make sure, Th Shooter pushes his chair back.
I know it's early, men, but what  about taking a little break? (TIME LAPSE)
Melba fills a beer glass from a bottle and serves it to T Shooter.
(to Melba) It always distresses me, a man  reaching his middle years and still  having no assurance of next week's  income.
I know what you mean. I like a man  to have plenty of assurance.

The Shooter's gaze wanders o.s. CAMERA MOVES to FEATURE t objects of his attention, who are Lady Fingers, Lancey an The Kid. The two men would like to talk to each other, bu Lady Finger's is monopolizing Lancey, and he doesn't want offend her.

Spider Man died kind of slow. First  he give them a kidney, then his gall  bladder, and then they taking his  whole damn stomach. You remember  Spider Man, run the dice table down  at Turk's Club to Memphis.
Who? Oh, Spider Man, sure, sure.
He died kind of slow.
The Shooter comes to Lancey's rescue.
Need your help, Lady Fingers... to  make arrangements for food and  shelter.
He whisks her away. Lancey and The Kid, finally facing ea other alone, don't quite know how to begin.
Good crowd.
Yeah. Nice-looking broads.
That's a fact.
That was a pretty thing to watch  what you done to Pig with those jacks.
Thanks, Kid. From you, that's nice  to hear.

When he bet out first, he was ready  to think you had them back to back.  Even when he bet the size of the  pot, he figured there was still a  chance you were laying for him. But  when you called him, I could see it  in his eyes he thought you had jacks  and tens, and I knew you had him  hooked.
You knew, did you? Before I raised?
Oh, sure, I seen what you were pulling  all along.
Lancey is a bit taken aback by The Kid's confident assert but he manages a smile.
You been to Miami, Kid?
Not yet.
Beautiful town, lot of loose money  around. You ought to come down some  time.
You mean it?
Sure, sure. Lot of room down there.  Another spot you ought to work someday  is Reno, Nevada.
I heard.
You got to have nerves though. So  much going on. Action everywhere you  turn. You lose the feel of the cards  when you're in so much action day  in, day out.
I'd like to make it out there.
There's different levels of action  there -- you'd find yours, any kind  you could ask for.
I generally stick to stud.
Sure, sure, for eating money. But  you know how it is, I like to lay  off once in a while and try craps.  Nothing serious -- I don't even think  of it as work.
Oh, I do that. I'll take a night off  and shoot a little casino. Or even  blackjack.

Your age, you don't need a regular  vacation every year. But me, I have  to forget the grind for a couple of  weeks. I go to this place near Delray  Beach, and the whole time I don't  play anything but bridge.
That's interesting. I could go for  bridge if there was a way to do it  without partners.
I'm not keeping you from your woman,  am I?
(after a slight  hesitation) No. We're -- she's gone away for a  while. We're not sure we're looking  for the same thing.
I'm sorry to hear that.
I was hoping Christian would run  with me and wouldn't try to make a  big deal out of it.
But she tried?

Yeah, and now I don't know. I don't  figure a man can change his way  because the way I see it a man's  lucky he's got something going for  him that he can hold on to. A man  can't change his way for a woman.
Nooo, a man can't do that.
I been wondering if it isn't maybe a  better idea not to look for a fixed  thing. Just tie in to something nice  when you're away from the action,  and enjoy it, and let it wear itself  out.
(after a long moment) That's very interesting you should  say that. You're pretty young to  have figured things out already.
Well she didn't understand how it  was with me and ---
(warmly) Between us?
There ain't but a few people, I guess  who would understand --
(as The Kid doesn't  finish) Kid, you're the best stud man I've  seen in 35 years of action. You know  that?
Well -- thank you.

And when it comes to broads, which  is getting to be an academic problem --  I can look back now to the two or  three I ever considered I might want  to spend the rest of my life with,  and you know what? I like it...  looking back on them, that is -- (then) I always got a lot of companionship  out of a good book.
It's very educational, hearing what  it's like for a man your age.
Glad to be of help. And it's good we  had this little talk so I know we  can be friends regardless what  happens.
That sounds good to me. I didn't  think you was coming in at me like a  grudge match.
No room for any kind of emotion in a  fair game of stud. I learned that a  long time ago.
Ready for some action, gentlemen.
They look at each other and then exit.

Lady Fingers is sitting in Shooter's place, rippling and  shuffling the cards. Yeller, Sokal, and The Shooter are a either sitting at the table or standing near it. Lancey,  followed by The Kid, returns to the table.
It's a whole New Deal. Good hands  all around. Prosperity for everybody.
You're still good, Fingers.
Getting crippled up, Lancey. Not  many of the old gang left. You heard  Whistling Sam was gone?
No, I didn't hear.
I was the one got called to the morgue  to identify him. I don't suppose you  seen anybody been run over by a twelve- ton bulldozer.
No, can't say that I have.
Don't go out of your way. (TIME LAPSE)
Morning sunlight is streaming in.
The Kid, facing the sun, wears his eyeshade. The Shooter resumed the deal and now hands out last cards to Sokal, T Kid and himself.
Bet the pot. Four hundred and twenty  dollars.
Fold.
It's yours.
Thanks, gents. Makes me exactly even.  This kind of a game, that's a smart  place to quit. (takes his money off  the table) Just do the dealing, if that's all  right with everybody. (TIME LAPSE)
It is later in the morning. Three players are left in the hand on the last card: Yeller with nothing higher than a  jack, Lancey with a king-queen showing and Sokal with an king.
Ace-king is the high man.
Shoot the works. (counts it out) Nine hundred and thirty bucks.
I'm over.
(putting out the money) What have you got?
(unhappily) Doesn't matter. If you can call me,  you beat me. Ace-king high.
(turning an ace) Ace-king-queen high.
(to The Kid) I had them both with a pair of fives.
Winds it up for me, men. And I can't  say it's been a pleasure. (despairingly) That one I was sure I could steal.
Lancey has a built-in burglar alarm.  I'm also withdrawing from the field  of battle, gentlemen. Settle for the  seventeen hundred I've already  dropped.
Yeller pulls in the money in front of him. There is now a $19,500 left on the table, $11,500 in front of Lancey, $8 in front of The Kid.
(to The Kid) Well, just the two of us.
Yeah, just the two of us. Deal them,  Shooter Man. (TIME LAPSE)
There is around $1,500 in the pot. Shooter deals an unhel card to Lancey's pair of aces, and a nine to The Kid's ki queen-ten.
Cost you a grand.
Compulsory call, Kid.
The Kid turns up a jack and pulls in the money. (TIME LAPSE)
The last bet has been made and there is about $3000 in th pot. Lancey exposes his hole card.
Two pair, jacks up.
Kings up.
He takes in the money. (TIME LAPSE)
There is $2500 in the pot. Lancey shows a pair of kings, Kid an ace and three odd cards. The Shooter deals a nine Lancey.

He is watching The Shooter intently. FEATURING THE SHOOTER'S HANDS - KID'S P.O.V. The dealing motion looks perfectly legitimate as The Shoo gives The Kid an ace. Lancey's hand reaches into the SHOT turn over his up cards.
Studded again.
He takes the money in slowly, his eyes on The Shooter. No the distribution of money has been reversed. The Kid has  something under $12,000, Lancey something under $8,000.
He avoids meeting The Kid's gaze. (TIME LAPSE)
On the fourth card Lancey shows a pair of sevens, The Kid pair of eights and a ten.
Two thousand dollars.
The Kid lifts his hole card and we see it is a ten.
Call two thousand.

He turns to watch The Shooter. FEATURING THE SHOOTER'S HANDS - KID'S P.O.V. Again there is no indication of improper dealing as The  Shooter gives Lancey an odd card and The Kid a ten, compl his full house.
Two thousand more.

Take it. I can't beat three sevens. (then as The Shooter's  eyes flicker with  surprise) I'd like a break to get some food  and sleep -- I'm winners so it isn't  up to me to say it but I'm saying it  anyway.
He exits. After a moment The Shooter follows. Lancey watc them go then rises, apparently still fresh and strong. La Fingers joins him.
(pleasantly) My dear, that young man is a stud  poker-playing son-of-a-bitch.
Gettin' to you, Lancey?
Lancey looks at her a moment, then smiles.
(softly) Not yet he isn't.
He moves through the crowd, then exits.
They are alone in the room. Shooter is uncomfortable and  would like to be elsewhere but The Kid is standing in fro of the closed door.
Now, just what the hell are you trying  to pull?
(trying to bluff it) Nothing -- what are you talking about?
The Kid grabs him and slams him against the wall.
You, Shooter Man -- you been feeding  me cards for an hour.
(angry and ashamed) The hell I was. (he waits a brief  moment then eases  away from The Kid) Christ, Kid, even if I was you  couldn't spot it -- I'm too good a  mechanic for anybody to spot it.
(grabbing him and  slamming him against  the wall again) But I was looking for it, Shooter --  four times you give me the cards I  need.
(a little shrill) You seen it before often enough. One  player draws four good ones.
Never in a game when I been told  ahead the dealer has a stake in my  coming out on top.
(slumping) My woman told you.
She told me enough to make me start  thinking.
(almost pleading) Why should you bitch if I give you a  little help?
Why, you dumb bastard? -- You have  to ask me why. (ready to hit him) I could break you apart for what  you've done.
(backing off) Kid, you got to understand. It wasn't  my idea --
Well who the hell's was it then --  Schlaegel? --

He's got the squeeze on me Kid and  he's meaner than hell. He'll cut me  up if I don't come through. (then) You think I wanted to deal a phony  game? You think it don't mean  something to me? I never done a  crooked thing before in my life.
My ass bleeds for you -- Now you get  straight on this. No fix. You come  along straight or I blow it wide  open.
He's liable to kill me.
He ain't goin' to do nothin' to you  except pay off because I'm goin' to  win.
It is a hell of a chance to take.
You got no choice.
He ain't goin' to like it.
(almost yelling at  him) He ain't goin' to know. (then quietly) Shooter, I'm goin' to win this one --  win it my way -- and you ride with  me or you're out, finished.
I ride with you.
You better not forget it -- now beat  it. I need some sleep.
Shooter looks at him, then moves towards the door.
Tell Mr. Schlaegel I accept his offer  to use the room.
The Shooter goes out. The Kid crosses to the phone.
(into phone) I want to be called at 4 p.m. on the  nose. For sure -- Thanks.
In the privacy of his room he shows how close he is to  exhaustion. Wearily, he sits on the bed and begins to rem his shoes. Then, catching his reflection in the mirror,  straightens.
Not yet he isn't. But he damn well  might.

She is in the final stages of undressing. CAMERA MOVES wi her as she steps to The Kid's bedside and gets into bed w him. Having accomplished this without waking him, she spe into his ear in imitation of a hotel phone operator.
Good afternoon, sir. It's exactly  four o'clock.
He awakens in considerable confusion. Melba is amused by difficulty in adjusting to his circumstances.
It's really only about twenty-five  to four. You can stay right where  you are.
I don't want you to think I'm getting  too personal, but you mind telling  me how the hell you come to be here?
You mean you don't remember last  night? We drank all that champagne  and you said "Let's get married right  away," and we chartered a plane to --
Can it -- (then) Where's Shooter?
I locked the door. It's incredible  the way you invariably worry about  The Shooter.
It's incredible the way you invariably  don't.
Worrying takes time and we don't  have a lot.
We're supposed to sit down again at  half past four.
Does it really matter so much to you  now, that sense of obligation to The  Shooter?
(thinking about Shooter) I got no obligations to The Shooter. (then to Melba) Or to you.
Obligations are not what I have in  mind.
He is shaving. Apparently much stronger but his hand is  shaking. He looks at it. It steadies. After a moment he s a little.
CAMERA is on the shower door as the SOUND of running wate ceases. The Kid can be seen indistinctly through the door
Reach me a towel?

Melba, who is dressed again and applying her lipstick, co into the SHOT, takes a towel from a rack and hands it to after he opens the shower door. He gives himself a quick  once-over with it, the secures it around his waist, steps out of the shower stall, and begins the process of shavin Melba meanwhile finishes restoring her makeup.
You any idea how much The Shooter  has involved in this game of yours?
If Schlaegel bet as much on me as I  heard, I guess he'd pay a nice piece  of change to be sure I won.
It's worse than that. Schlaegel staked  him for three years. He has his hooks  so deep in Shooter Man, he'll take  out his liver when he pulls them  out.
The Kid stops shaving and looks at her.
You asking me to go along with the  fix?
I'm asking you to consider whether  your ego is worth destroying another  man's whole life.
You're still working for him. On my  time you're still working for him.
What kind of switch is this? You  criticize me for trying to chippie  on him, then I get a little loyal  and you're at me for that.
No -- I don't hold it against you.  You wanting to make things right for  him -- but this game I handle my way --  win, lose, or draw.
There is a KNOCK on the door.
Rolls and coffee for the hard-headed  hero.
CAMERA PANS to take in the view of the bedroom as she cro it to the door, talking as she goes.
Believe me Kid there is too much at  stake for us to rely on your doing  it on your own.

She has paused at the door to finish her sentence. Now sh unlocks and opens it -- to Christian. Melba is so taken a she can't do anything but stand there holding the door op The Kid, in the bathroom in f.g., is similarly frozen in tracks. After a moment Christian advances into the room. REVERSE ANGLE - CHRISTIAN IN F.G. The scene as it looks to Christian is circumstantially  incriminating. CAMERA MOVES with her gaze from The Kid to the one mussed bed, to Melba. The faces and the silence o the two people are even more incriminating than the  circumstances.
Hello, Kid. Hello, Melba. (a pause) You said wait home 'til you let me  know.
Yeah, that's what I said. We took a  break in the game to catch some sleep.  Shooter sent his woman up here to  wake me up.
Yeah, I woke him up.
It don't take much.
No, I didn't find it any trouble. (awkwardly) Well, you children don't need me,  that's for sure. See you downstairs. (to Christian) You, too, honey, right?
I'll be around if The Kid wants me.
See you, Melba. Thanks.
Por nada, as they say. It was nothing.

She walks past CAMERA and a moment later comes the SOUND the door closing behind her. The Kid, who has moved into bedroom, crosses to his clothes on a chair, and picks up undershorts and trousers. He returns to the bathroom, usi the door for partial concealment as he removes his towel puts on his shorts and trousers.
You been to the place?
No, I've got my bag downstairs. Maybe  I'll take it over later on tonight.
How's your Mama and Papa?
Fine. How's the game going?
The Kid fastens his trousers and returns to the basin to  give his face a last few strokes with the razor and wash the soap.
It's come to be just me and Lancey.
He comes back into the bedroom to finish dressing. As his movement brings him fairly close to Christian, he realize he hasn't kissed her, and repairs the omission before put his shirt on.
(after the kiss) I was wondering.
I got my mind on the cards.

I know. And I don't want to rattle  you. We got plenty to talk about,  but it can all wait. Except I want  to say this. I came back because I  figured if it was going to work with  us, it's silly me sitting home with  Mama while you're playing your big  game. I mean if I'm any use to you  at all, this is when it's most  important.
To The Kid preoccupied by the game and the fix, feeling b affection and guilt. The idea that she can be any use to against Lancey is one he can't grasp.
I'm glad you came, Christian. You  got as much right here as anybody. (then) More right, I should have said.
Should you?
Hell, yes. The change I come out  with when I win this one, you're  going to be the one to spend it.
He moves toward the door.
Eric --
(turning back) Look, I said I'm glad you came --  and that's all until I wrap this up --  I'm a poker player, remember?
She looks at him. After a moment he exits. She follows.
It is evening. Lady Fingers deals a first up card to the players. The Kid gets an eight, Lancey a jack.
The eight'll try two bills.
(turning his card) No stay.

Lady Fingers scoops up the cards, shuffles them into the  rest of the deck, submits it to Lancey for his cut, and d them another two cards apiece -- all in the space of seco The Kid gets a queen, Lancey a nine.
Two hundred.
(turning his card) No stay.
CAMERA starts on Yeller, who is stretched out on the love with his eyes closed and PANS UP to INCLUDE Hoban, who si at the observation post with the binoculars. Yeller speak without opening his eyes.
Anything?
Naaa, Kid paired kings. He wins a  hundred.

CAMERA MOVES on PAST a window, showing it is night outsid past a group of other spectators; past Bill, Shooter and  Melba who watch the game grimly; and finally to the table where The Shooter is dealing again. The Kid is down to hi undershirt, and even Lancey has made a few concessions to comfort. The players have just been dealt their third car Christian moves up to stand behind The Kid.
Queen bets another C-note.
(folding) Take it away.
He looks up at Christian.
Go read a magazine, honey.
She hesitates. Then moves away. Lancey watches this. (TIME LAPSE)
It is later at night. The magazine lies open on Christian lap; she is staring absently into space.
All right, gents. I'm declaring a  break.
The announcement rouses Christian from her reverie.
Lady Fingers is in the dealer's chair. The two players lo pretty weary.
I break.
I don't want a break.
Well, I don't either.
Deal.
Lady Fingers puts down the deck. Picks up a new one.
(snapping) Same deck is good enough.
I want a new deck.
Alright, alright -- A new deck then,  Jesus.
Deal.
Lady Fingers looks at the two men for a long moment. Puts the cards down.

You want to deal? Then deal them  yourselves. I'm going to the john.  I'm going to get something to eat,  and I'm going to take a nap. You  barracudas can snap all you want but  at each other -- I'm taking a break  and if you don't like it you can  both go to hell.
She turns and stalks off. Lancey and The Kid look at each other for a moment, then both grin.
I guess we been told.
Looks that way.
(rising) See you in about 3/4 of an hour,  Lancey, right?
Make it an hour. Old bones need a  little more time to loosen up.
(meaning it) Listen, I think it is amazing you've  been able to keep going this long.

As he heads for the door, Lancey reacts to this. Then sta and looks around the room. Groups of people stand in the  shadows watching silently, not hostile but certainly not  friendly. He is The Man but he is getting beat and nobody sorry. After a moment he turns and leaves from a side doo CAMERA PANS to HOLD on Christian as she stops The Kid by door.
(taking his hand) Eric --
(simultaneously) Your fan on the fifth floor wants  you to have a bite with him. Alone.
There's nothing to talk about.
You better, Kid. You don't, you're  only making worse trouble.
Christian scans both their faces as they talk... concerne
If you think so. (to Christian) Sorry.
What's wrong?
Nothing, Nothing you have to worry  about. I'll see you later.
He heads for the door. Christian looks after him.
Get something to eat.
Bill and The Kid are sitting at a room-service table. Bil nibbles at some cheese and crackers while The Kid tackles large steak. Felix, the chauffeur, stands in attendance o them.
I thought it would be better if you  and I sat down together to see if we  couldn't work out our differences.  Felix!
He motions to Felix, indicating a wine bottle on the tabl Felix steps over and refills The Kid's glass.
What I told The Shooter goes.
Are you saying no before we've even  discussed it? Am I to feel all my  arguments will be wasted?
The Kid just looks at him -- then returns to his meal.
I'll skip to the final argument. (then) More salad, perhaps?
He makes a peremptory gesture to Felix, who springs forwa to offer the salad bowl to The Kid.
The Shooter will be back dealing  when you start again. He will give  you an occasional helpful card.
That's an argument?
That's a fact. I'm coming to the  argument.
I'll give you a fact. I won't let it  happen.
Is that knife sharp enough? Felix.

Felix jumps into action again. He moves to The Kid's side reaches into a breast pocket and takes out a switch blade which he clocks open an inch or two from The Kid's neck. is an extremely ugly-looking and menacing weapon.
See if it cuts better with that.
Felix hands the knife to The Kid, who tries it on his ste
Sharp?
Very. But it don't cut any ice with  me.
He jams the knife in the table and snaps off the blade.
(rising) Not this time. He exits.
As The Kid exits Christian is waiting for him. He moves d the corridor, preoccupied. She follows.
Did you eat?
No.
(stops, looks at her  irritated) Why not, for Chris sakes?
Eric --
(moving away) You should eat something.
(loudly, stopping) I've got to talk to you.
He stops, looks at her.
Talk.
(fumbling) It's -- about us. What's going to  happen?
(interrupting) What's going to happen? What's going  to happen for Chris sake is I'm going  to win the game. (then more softly) You go back to the apartment, honey,  this might take two more days.
(flatly) If I go, I'm not going back to the  apartment. If I go -- I'm just going.
(after a long moment) Well, that's up to you, Christian.
He looks at her a moment longer then moves up the corrido She watches him, then turns. Standing in the open door so distance away are Schlaegel and Felix.

Shuffling the cards. CAMERA PULLS BACK enough to see his  face as he looks across at The Kid. CAMERA PANS to a CLOS SHOT of The Kid, and then past a couple of spectators,  including Christian and Melba, to Bill, whose eyes are on The Kid. Finally CAMERA PANS back to The Kid.
I told you, Shooter -- I won't go  for it.
Both The Shooter and Bill are aware of a portentous note The Kid's tone.
What's up?
The Shooter's not well. He didn't  want to spoil the game, but he ought  to be resting... He ought to be in  the hospital.
Well, we got Lady Fingers. Or we can  deal ourselves.
I'm okay. What The Kid's talking  about is nothing. It's just not  important.
It is to me... You want to kill  yourself, do it on your own time.
Lancey looks from The Kid to The Shooter, sensing that th may be something more behind this, but not knowing just w
I got to go along with that, Shooter.  Lady Fingers! You ready?
Rising from her chair.
Like Eddie the Dude said on his  deathbed, I'm as ready as I'll ever  be. (TIME LAPSE)

The four cards showing are the ace, ten and two little cl As CAMERA PULLS BACK we also have time to note The Kid's  stake. He is still ahead. Lancey counts out five hundred  dollars from his stake, leaving about thirteen thousand, puts it into a pot that already contains around a thousan
I can't persuade myself you have the  flush.
The Kid turns up the jack of clubs.
Now I can.
The Kid pulls in the money. (TIME LAPSE)
Both men are showing the strain. Perhaps Lancey the most he appears to be consistently losing. Showing are two nin and two odd cards.
I'm going to pay the price to look  at that third nine.
The kid turns up another nine and reaches for the money.
Caveat emptor. New deck, please. (TIME LAPSE)
He shows a pair of eights and two odd cards against Lance pair of queens. He takes another look at his hole card, a we see that it is of no help to him.
Pair of eights bets an even thousand  dollars.
They are both sitting on the back of the loveseat now. Th binoculars pass from one to the other. Both men are tense over the growing excitement of the game.
Ten bucks and my notoriously fallible  instinct tells me the boy is bluffing  this time.
Mark it.
CAMERA MOVES to the other four remaining spectators:  Christian, Melba, The Shooter and Bill. They are close en to see the cards but too close to discuss them.
The kid has almost half the money in front of him now, an is playing with increasing assurance and pressure.
(turning his cards) I'm not that curious.
(excitement in his  voice) The Kid is pushing it and making it  stick.
CAMERA MOVES to the other four spectators as they react t The Kid's successful streak.
(in a low voice) He's getting to him.

And it looks that way. Lancey appears old and unsure. The Kid sharp and cold. A young barracuda moving in for the k CAMERA MOVES in close to Christian as she tries to catch Kid's eye. Thinking she has it, she smiles her encouragem
He looks right at her and doesn't seem to see her. Lady  Fingers has dealt the first up cards of a new hand, and L is high.
Two hundred.
And up five.
Fold.
Amid the growing excitement and tension she is a complete outsider. (TIME LAPSE)
The Kid shows two jacks and two odd cards; Lancey a pair aces and two odd cards. Lancey puts about eight hundred  dollars into the pot.
Betting the jack isn't there, Kid.
The Kid exposes his hidden jack.
Greed and an almost vicious satisfaction marks their face as they watch Lancey falter. The Shooter whispers to Bill just loud enough for the girl to hear.
We're in -- I think he's got him.

Christian looks at them, then at The Kid. Hesitates a mom then suddenly gets to her feet and starts for the door. O Melba notices her, and even she doesn't have time to ques her. CAMERA FOLLOWS Christian to the suite entrance, wher she picks up her bag then turns to look back at the table
The place where Christian was sitting is right in his lin of vision but he hasn't observed her departure.
She goes on out the door.

The second dawn of the contest is near at hand. The room, continuously lived in for so long by so many people, is a shambles of dirty glasses and plates, empty bottles, full wastebaskets and ash trays, and frayed people. At the pok table, Lady Fingers is dealing a new hand.
A jack and a ten. Jack bets.
CAMERA MOVES in close enough for us to see the cards. Lan has the jack of hearts, The Kid the ten of clubs.
Jack is willing to wager two hundred  dollars.
The Kid takes his first look at his hole card.
It is the queen of hearts.
And up five hundred.

Lancey looks at him a long moment. His face pale and shak The Kid is beating him. Pushing -- buying -- always press and Lancey knows he is losing one hand at a time, not bad but consistently and inevitably. His age and fatigue are strong handicap for the long pull. Then his face settles if he had come to a decision. He smiles lightly summoning some last reserve of strength, almost as if he knows this will be the last hand, win or lose.
Call your five hundred and five  hundred more.
(after a brief  hesitation) Call.
Fifty to one hundred says Lancey  paired his jacks.
Mark it.
Lady Fingers deals the ten of diamonds to The Kid, giving him a pair, and the ten of hearts to Lancey.
Pair of tens. Jack, ten of hearts.
Five hundred.
Your five hundred -- and up one  thousand.
The raise is a surprise. The Kid's eyes go up to study  Lancey's face, even though he knows what a futile effort  that is.
Fifty to seventy-five he's got the  jacks wired.
Mark it -- Could be a high heart.  Queen's the best, but that old man  can be cocky with an ace or a deuce.  'Specially having one of The Kid's  tens.
One thousand to the tens.
Call.
(dealing) A third ten, and a nine of hearts to  the ten, jack.
The Kid, Lancey, Shooter, Melba, Schlaegel, Yeller, Hoban and others as they realize this could be the big hand.
He'll run. He's beat on the board  anyway you look at it. Even if he  has the jacks it is better than eight  to one against improving.
He won't run and I don't think he's  got the jacks. I think he's going  for the flush.
(after a moment) Two thousand, five hundred dollars.
Lancey looks at him, then at the cards. The moment stretc
(finally) Two thousand, five hundred dollars  to the three hearts.
Lancey looks at her. His face briefly showing his anger. Kid notices this and reacts.
(finally, casually) Reasonable bet. Two thousand five  hundred. (he counts out the  money to Lady Fingers) Deal them.
(knowing this is it) He's going for it and The Kid's got  him. He's going all the way.
(dealing) A queen of diamonds to the three  tens. (a note of excitement  in her voice) And an eight of hearts to the possible  flush. Possible straight flush. Three  tens bet.
The Kid checks the amount of money in front of him.
They exchange a quick look of satisfaction, and then thei eyes go back to the cards.
They each take a quick turn with the binoculars.
If The Kid bets into the flush he's  filled up with a queen in the hole.
If The Man has a flush or a straight,  he goes under. (then) But not with both.

He looks at his hole card. It is still the queen of heart He has a full house, which has to be the winning hand unl Lancey had the audacity to bet out with a jack-seven of  hearts, and to raise The Kid with a jack-ten-seven.
Bet what's in front of me. Make it  fifty-four hundred bucks.
He counts out all his money except a few smaller bills.
Reacting.
He takes his time before he responds.
Fifty-four hundred bucks is a nice  piece of money. (counting it out) I see the bet and raise sixty-seven  hundred.
Slowly and deliberately, revealing nothing in his face, h reaches into his breast pocket and takes out a slim walle and begins to let the bills flutter out on the table. The Kid looks at him frozen.
Bill hisses softly into The Shooter's ear.
Kid has him, doesn't he?
But The Shooter, like the Kid, is white-faced and frozen the raise.
They crowd in close to the table: Hoban, Yeller, Bill, Th Shooter, and Melba.
(after a long moment) I'm taking my half hour to raise my  stake.
I declare a thirty-minute break.  Leave your cards and money on the  table. The game will start again at  five forty-five.
I'll take your marker, Kid.
I can raise it.
I know you can.
Long as you know. (he raps the table) -- Call.
(turns up a heart  seven) Straight flush to the jack -- That's  $6700 you owe me, Kid.

There is nothing to be gained from a poker face now, and reacts with a stunned expression in which all the accumul strain and fatigue is beginning to show. CAMERA MOVES amo the spectators: Hoban and Yeller, who are sorry for The K and admiring of Lancey; Bill, who is all the more angry a his defeat because his hopes were up; The Shooter, who is very unhappy man; and Melba, whose anger at the Kid is  balanced by her fear of Schlaegel and what will happen to The Shooter and possibly to her.
Lancey pulls in the money while The Kid stares at him dum Lady Fingers riffles the cards.
New deck.
Are you playing, Kid? You got a half  an hour to raise your stake.
No -- I'm through.
(formally) Gentlemen, this game is over.
You're one hell of a poker player,  Kid. That was a rough hand.
Thanks.
What's the tab for the whole show?
As he settles up, the CAMERA FOLLOWS The Kid to his brand bottle. As he pours himself a slug, Melba and Shooter joi him.
You had to do it, didn't you -- you  had to go for it your own way. (then, as The Kid  doesn't answer) Well, sonny, I hope you learned  something. I know we sure as hell  did.
Where's Christian?
She's gone. She's got too much sense  to stick with a two bit loser.
Shut up. (then:) Sorry, Kid.
Yeah. (then:) I should have known he had it, Shooter  Man. I walked into it.
(trying to grin as  Schlaegel and Felix  move up) Well, Kid, it's like I said -- you  just wasn't ready.
(to The Shooter) Are you ready, Shooter Man? We're  having a meeting and I suggest you  join us.
Shooter looks at him a moment and nods, and taking Melba the arm, moves toward the door followed by Felix.
Why me -- I'm not part of this.
(jerking her forward) Oh, yes you are -- you and your big  mouth -- you're part of it all right.
He's right, my dear. Now run along  with Felix. We're going to have a  long talk about that big mouth of  yours.
Melba starts to protest, but Felix jerks her out the door Shooter hesitates, then follows.
Schlaegel turns to The Kid.

I was wrong. I figured you for brains.  But you're a loser, Kid. You had a  chance to play with grownups and you  ran. (then, as Lancey and  Lady Fingers approach) They weren't playing your game. They  were playing mine. Think about that  while you find a place to hide. But  hide good, Kid -- because I got a  message for you and I'm going to see  it delivered.
The Kid looks at him, looks at Lancey and Lady Fingers,  wondering about what Schlaegel has said, angry about it.
Any time.
Schlaegel nods, moves to the door.
Lancey and Lady Fingers join The Kid.
Never thought I'd see the day. You  raising tens on a lousy three-flush.
Gets down to what it's all about,  doesn't it? Making the wrong play at  the right time.
(sharply) That's what it's all about? (then, as Lancey looks  at him and doesn't  answer) You were crazy -- odds are three  hundred to one against.

(after a moment) I don't play a percentage game. I  play stud poker my way. And I got  the money and you got the questions.  Figure that out. (then, not unkindly) You're good. But as long as I'm  around, you're second best, Kid...  and you might as well learn to live  with it.
The Kid looks at him and doesn't answer.
Look me up if you're in Miami after  Christmas. Stillson Hotel.
He smiles his very pleasant smile and goes out the door.
Lancey stops surrounded by a crowd of admirers offering t congratulations. The Kid watches for a moment then takes long drink out of the bottle and eases through the crowd out the door.
as The Kid moves down the hall and enters the elevator.
as he moves through the almost deserted lobby into the st
SERIES OF ANGLES of the Kid walking alone through the cit During the above there is an impression someone is follow him.

location: DESERTED STREET NEAR THE KID'S APARTMENT

text: He turns a corner and there is a man blocking his path.  Suddenly three men move in behind him. He turns, trapped.

The men are four of the original seven players he hustled the opening scene. NOTE: During the progression of the game first one, then  two, then all four men will be included among the observe Always in the background, never positively identified. Th presence should be felt if not recognized.
So it ain't Eric Stone, from the  foundry. It's the Cincinnati Kid  King of the stud poker players.
No -- not the King -- not much of  anything right now.
(moving towards him) We'll start with giving you back  what you gave me.
He moves toward The Kid.
Eric --
The men hesitate.
as Christian gets out of a taxi.
(as she moves toward  them) Tell her good-bye, sport. You ain't  going any place.
I know that.
He crosses to Christian.
Are you all right?
I'm fine. (then) Weren't you going to say good-bye?
I said good-bye.
Yeah, I guess you did. (then) You don't know if I won or lost do  you?
No -- it doesn't really matter. (then after a long  moment) I love you, Kid -- and it's not  enough.
Yeah, I know.
(calling) Listen, Lady, it's coming on the  morning rush. I got to have one fare  after another or I'm behind for the  day.
Christian doesn't answer. She looks at The Kid for a long moment, then turns and goes. He watches her. She enters t cab and it leaves. The Kid just stands there.

Danny and the others move up around him. The Kid ignores  them. After a moment Danny swings from behind and knocks to the pavement. He lies there stunned for a moment. They look down at him. Then he comes up. He flattens two in th process of being badly beaten. They leave him.
as the city awakens. Finally, he stirs, stands and walks  away.
